item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: There were a couple more [moments] that I thought were revealing enough and I loved the intent.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I still think it's worth renting because the film does a good job of taking audiences deeper than the media or newscasters on TV ever could, personalizing and humanizing war and its impact on the American family.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: A lot more dimensional and complex than its sunny disposition would lead you to believe.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Makes the sweet case that sincerity strikes the biggest romantic sparks.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie's attention to cultural context really does separate it from anything that came before, including the winning, but finally irrelevant, When Harry Met Sally...

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: As satisfying as it is sleek, and Famuyiwa inspires carefully nuanced portrayals from his cast.

item.content: ... on at least three or four occasions, Carrey made me laugh so hard I had tears in my eyes -- and that's a heck of a trick.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Carrey] is in loose-limbed form, with healthy doses of fury, in a film that mostly succeeds at fusing his slapstick talents and more heartfelt inclinations.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The laughs in Bruce Almighty are thinly spread across a vast, bland cake of uplifting sentiment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Carrey] is so gifted a physical comedian that even mediocre material shines in his talented hands.

item.label: rotten

item.content: This isn't even a series of skits, but a series of vague ideas for skits that nobody fleshed out.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Through all this, one feels nothing more strongly than an acute sympathy for all involved -- in particular Ricci, who gives her role more than it deserves, and Herrmann, a classy character actor who once won a Tony.

item.content: Bug won't get under your skin as much as it will assault you with its ghastly claustrophobic drama and over-the-top performances.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The cheesy soundtrack and the lacklustre acting undermine [director Friedkin's] efforts at turning an intelligent play into a scary movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bug may not be a big deal, but it is a sublime and remarkably disturbing small deal that pays and demands close attention.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: After nearly three decades of misfires, major and minor, William Friedkin, the creator of The French Connection, The Exorcist and Sorcerer, is back in true form with Bug.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bug is a twisted, visceral film with an uncompromising sense of nihilism.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ron Shelton, who wrote and directed the film, displays a knowledge of and affection for the national pastime. You can see it in the knowing detail he brings to even the minor characters.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Shelton is] uncanny at putting us inside his players' heads when they're on the mound or up at bat, running their private litanies of encouragement and subversion to psych themselves up.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The acting in Bull Durham cannot be faulted and should be remembered at Oscar time. Sarandon has one of the juiciest female roles in years and she makes you think no one could play it better.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Shelton locates the tension and the humor between pitches, between ball games, between the sheets. It helps too that he has written the wittiest, busiest screenplay since Moonstruck, and that his three stars do their very best screen work.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Costner is a natural as the dyed-in-the-wool ballplayer. His best lines are when he's philosophizing, like on being an All-American male who hates anything by Susan Sontag.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Marvellous stuff.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bull Durham is a film with spring fever, a giddy, playful look at life in baseball's minor leagues.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bull Durham, the new baseball movie starring Kevin Costner and Susan Sarandon, eases up on you, lazy as a cloud, and carries you off in a mood of exquisite delight.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bull Durham is a treasure of a movie because it knows so much about baseball and so little about love.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Writer/director Ron Shelton lobs juicy lines to players Kevin Costner, Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins, and they all hit home.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If one was to make a list of the best baseball-themed movies of all time, Bull Durham would have to be in consideration.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Stallone can still be entertaining, but here he's got no character to play, nothing fun to say, and the craziest hair/hairpiece/scalp growth this side of John Travolta.

item.content: The Geritol action genre lumbers on in the lackluster \"Bullet to the Head,\" starring Sylvester Stallone, or at least a beef jerky replica.

item.content: In \"Bullet to the Head\" violence is abrupt, shattering and consequential. It's not for laughs. It's graphic and unsettling, and it makes us feel uneasy, as we should, about the world the characters inhabit.

item.content: No! Don't speak! See it!

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.content: Stallone can still be entertaining, but here he's got no character to play, nothing fun to say, and the craziest hair/hairpiece/scalp growth this side of John Travolta.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: McQueen is great in Bullitt, and the movie is great, because director Peter Yates understands the McQueen image and works within it. He winds up with about the best action movie of recent years.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a sharp, brave movie, a little ragged around the edges, but that's to its advantage.

item.content: What gives Bulworth its unique character is that all this silliness is periodically punctuated by cogent, carefully thought-out mini-manifestos...

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bulworth works, with both urbanity and chutzpah, by viewing political puppeteering with an all-purpose jaundiced eye.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: A shrewd political observer for decades, Beatty has fashioned a hilarious morality tale that delivers a surprisingly potent, angry message beneath the laughs.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bulworth is an angry movie, but Beatty is savvy enough to recognize that people respond better to comedies than serious \"issue films,\" so he has camouflaged his message beneath the surface of this original, incisive satire.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bulworth plays like a cry of frustrated comic rage. It's about an archetypal character who increasingly seems to stand for our national mood: the guy who's fed up and isn't going to take it anymore.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Buried, despite its seemingly impossible premise, is by turns funny, suspenseful, moving and -- in one heart-stopping sequence worthy of Indiana Jones -- incredibly exciting.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Buried may be claustrophobic in scale, but its impact is immense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If the aim is to be unpredictable and to revel in cynicism, you run the risk -- realized here -- that the movie becomes more an authorial statement of purpose than a story the audience can believe in.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: At its best, Buried is a filmmaker's fondest double-dare challenge. And at its very best, it's considerably more.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a solid, unsettling, at times very entertaining thriller -- but the jury's still out on Reynolds.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Either Mr. Reynolds was directed to rant and rave, or his bellowing tantrums are meant to signal that Paul is a childish fool who isn't very bright.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: On a technical level Buried is impressive, at times blisteringly suspenseful, making the most of a ripping score and Reynolds' fully charged agony...

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: Nothing this underrated actor has done previously measures up to the emotional diversity, focus and self-control required of him in a one-man exercise in underground suspense that Alfred Hitchcock would envy.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Falling in the pillowy cleavage between mildly awful and slightly entertaining, Burlesque is a cliched rags-to-diva story that culminates in a series of Christina Aguilera videos.

item.content: For fans of the Coens... it suggests, especially on the heels of No Country for Old Men, that they have rediscovered their cinematic vision after several lean years.

item.content: On screen, delusional schmoes are more fun than smart people, and in the latest film from Joel and Ethan Coen, the imperious former spook played by John Malkovich accuses his blackmailers...of heading a league of morons.

item.content: Burn After Reading is a piffle, but it's a savagely amusing one.

item.label: fresh
item.content: After the portentous No Country for Old Men, Joel and Ethan Coen return to their trademark brand of cruel, misanthropic farce, and for dark laughs and hurtling narrative momentum this spy caper is their best work since Fargo.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Burn After Reading could just as well have been called Forget After Seeing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The brisk pace and sharp humor in Burn After Reading is a welcome relief after weeks of witless comedies and overblown action flicks.

item.label: fresh
item.content: None of it makes strict sense, which is why it's called screwball, but in its own crazy way Burn After Reading nails the essential folly of humans pretending to be civilized.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A cruelly, insanely hilarious comedy populated with imbeciles whose appetites lead to giant helpings of Just Desserts.

item.content: In the end, the movie doesn't add up to much, but it's fast and funny and lets a bunch of top-drawer actors exercise their comic muscles.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film is hilarious in patches, shocking in patches, utterly convincing in patches and close to brilliant in patches.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Extremely well-cast. Extremely well-written, too (with one of those clockwork plots -- beloved of the Coens since Blood Simple -- in which people, fatally, act before getting all the facts).

item.label: rotten
item.content: Most audiences will find it a head-scratcher with a dismaying act of violence and a haphazard plot that fizzles out without any of the main characters on-screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A cartoonish spoof of espionage thrillers, Burn After Reading comes on so goofily that you don't notice the pessimistic undertone right away.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Burn After Reading is neither an instant classic like No Country for Old Men nor a psychedelic playground like The Big Lebowski. But it is a Coen brothers kick in the pants.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A thoroughly disposable comic romp made by a bunch of people who probably should have been working on bigger and better things, Burn After Reading is sure to frustrate just about anyone who goes to see it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The ensemble is at once loose and pitch perfect. Hardly a one of them plays a wholly likable person, yet each reveals the despearate or stupid humanity of their characters.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As a chance to watch a gaggle of Serious Actors ham it up in an intricately plotted (though easy to follow) yarn, it's a well-executed diversion.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The difference between Burn After Reading and much better Coen comedies like Raising Arizona, Fargo, and O Brother, Where Art Thou? is that the brothers' smugness has finally gone over the top.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Best of all may be the narration, by Sam Shepard: His voice, the kind of voice God might have if he'd ever smoked Camels, frames this gentle but potent little story with good-natured authority, making it feel modern and ageless at once.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Charlotte's Web, with its insistently 'magical' theme music, an overbearing climax and a trough full of bad jokes, is merely adequate.

item.content: If you're looking for eye-popping evidence that the world's glaciers are melting, don't miss the small-scale but spectacular documentary, Chasing Ice.

item.content: The rapid disappearance of ice mountains, filmed over a period of years, is compressed through time-lapse technology into minutes and seconds. The speeded-up effect is harrowing and also, disturbingly, eerily beautiful.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie might have given us a bit less of Balog and a bit more of the startling sequences he produced.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though the filmmaker's point of view on the matter seems quite clear, Orlowski does smartly acknowledge counterarguments against climate change without dwelling on them.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You couldn't ask for a more dramatic moment than the climactic sequence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Chasing Ice\" aims to accomplish, with pictures, what all the hot air that has been generated on the subject of global warming hasn't been able to do: make a difference.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The photography is often beautiful (the blue glaciers sparkle in the sun like massive sapphires), but it's disturbing - and sure to convince any climate-change doubters.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As much as one may intellectually believe in climate change, to see it actually happening has the power to stun a viewer into wordlessness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The \"green\" teams looking into such energy sources as solar, wind and nuclear are often ridiculed. Watch \"Chasing Ice\" and see if you laugh.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Terribly, chillingly important.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The last words, four and simple, rightly belong to Balog: \"You can't deny it.\" No doubt - the iceman cometh.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As watchable as it is important.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What sustains the film are neither words nor music but spectacular images of places few people have ever seen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You won't want to look away - not only because of the gorgeous images, but also because of the reality it presents.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Considering the gravity of the situation there is very little preaching in Chasing Ice. Facts about global warming are presented then backed up with staggering visuals. An audience is invited to accept it as proof, or not.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jeff Orlowski's beautiful yet sobering documentary about the world's rapidly melting ice caps.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Forgettable fluff but it left me in an unaccountably bad mood, mainly because it's a step back for Mandy Moore.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Moore's lip-glossed petulance never catches fire with Goode's canned drollery.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's one TV-movie romp that Kristy McNichol never got around to starring in.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chasing Liberty will probably win over as many fuddy-duddy fathers as fillies with its mixture of sweetness tempered with genial cynicism.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An endless, virtually laugh-free pastiche of Aaron Sorkin by way of Aaron Spelling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Chasing Liberty is strictly vanilla-flavoured, status quo entertainment.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A fluffy romance vehicle that does manage a few charms.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's all quite engaging.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Movies don't get more disposable than this one.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It defines blah.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A feather-light, doggedly formulaic romantic comedy that's almost instantly forgettable despite the sunny presence of teen queen Mandy Moore.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Chasing Liberty is a comedy with no sense of fun, a romance with no passion.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film does provide some nice shots of Venice and offers one solid reason to display a little patriotic fervor: We do have the freedom to avoid such rote, shallow dullness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chasing Liberty is fine (if empty) fun, and much credit for that should go to feisty Moore.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Chasing Liberty is a many-unsplendoured thing, but the one thing it isn't is a movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: One of those efficiently made formula films that keeps movie houses open during the early part of the year.

item.label: rotten
item.content: No more than a series of postcard backdrops.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I'm not even sure it deserves to be called a movie. It's more a package built from Moore's smile, adolescent ideas about romance and plenty of picture-postcard photography.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [A] happy trip.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's a perfect fortune cookie of a movie, full of bland life lessons for everybody; would that there were some drama or style in it somewhere along the way.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For Hanson and Apted, this is a rather inconsequential effort.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The heart-pounding surfing scenes are epic but the script can barely keep its head above the waves in the dramatized biopic Chasing Mavericks.

item.label: rotten
item.content: When every frayed plot device you've predicted makes its inevitable appearance, at least you'll have the majestic waves off the California coastline to comfort you.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Never really [delivers] the sun-in-your-face, salt-in-your-hair, sandy-cocky thrill of surfing or surf culture.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: The tsunami of schmaltzy melodrama ... threatens to swamp the proceedings, which at heart are actually kind of thrilling and inspirational.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With the massive power and mesmerizing curl of the giant waves, Chasing Mavericks is at its best offshore.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Chasing Mavericks\" moves as fast as a runner in waist-high water and wears out its welcome.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The outstanding big-wave footage proves more credible than the overfamiliar dramatics in Chasing Mavericks.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Chasing Mavericks\" falls into the \"Machine Gun\" category of disappointments - at best it's a wash.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The surfers and the surfing, along with the natural beauty of the California coastline, help balance the movie's weak areas, including its lamentably one-dimensional protagonist.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The sinking feeling starts as soon as \"Chasing Mavericks\" opens, with Gerard Butler's solemn narration: \"We all come from the sea,\" he intones, \"but we are not all of the sea.\"

item.label: rotten
item.content: With a storyline as by-the-numbers as a square dance, the movie's one surprise comes with the closing credits -- namely, that this trite \"inspirational\" movie is the product of two world-class filmmakers, Curtis Hanson and Michael Apted.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A family movie of aggravating blandness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chasing Mavericks manages to sufficiently overcome the obstacles with admittedly affecting results.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Nothing special; decent enough considering the circumstances.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Chasing Mavericks\" invents minor conflicts but avoids major problems, coming off less like a biographical drama than a visit from a guest lecturer during Sunday school.

item.label: fresh

item.content: The new plot has all the appeal of a seaweed sandwich, being dark, salty, and indigestible.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: In every other way -- as adventure yarn or as satire on that form or merely as an enjoyable entertainment featuring a wonderfully sly and subtle actor -- it is not merely a loser. It is a disaster.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For the most part, Dead Man's Chest stands on its own and even makes a few halfhearted attempts to say something.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Calling a summer movie 'action-packed' is supposed to be a compliment, but there's nothing so tedious as nonstop excitement.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's often unclear what's going on, beyond a zillion dollars of splashy effects washing over the screen.

item.label: rotten
item.content: All of it evidently based on another notion, that great length equals great importance.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest is the worst kind of sequel -- the kind that exists only to give you more-more-more of what you liked the first time around, without ever justifying its own existence.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Although there are memorable bits and pieces, the new Pirates of the Caribbean is a movie with no particular interest in coherence, economy or feeling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's a franchise movie -- a product -- that is pretending to be a lot hipper than it is.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A bustling sequel that outperforms its predecessor as a special-effects extravaganza but one that can't match the feeling of discovery that came with the original.

item.content: Standard-issue genre accessories (dank stairways, flashlights, overcast skies, frosty windows) abound; shocks are mild and few.

item.label: rotten

item.content: The lack of suspense and surprise in this dispiritingly rote film becomes its own form of contamination.

item.content: It takes a good hour for one of the leads to suggest that \"we need to be smart about this.\" You want to be smart? Don't take an unauthorized tour of a nuclear disaster site.

item.content: Chernobyl Diaries is afflicted with a fatal flaw that damages many horror films: after a better-than-average setup and a promising first half, everything falls apart.

item.content: Avoid a boredom meltdown and give this formulaic scarefest a wide berth.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A most beautiful film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Cherry Blossoms is both austere and garish, simultaneously dry and sentimental, tightly repressed and extravagantly expressive, bourgeois and bohemian. It's a seesaw, but [director] Dorrie finds the balance.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Yearning for Ozu, Dorrie stops off at cute, and parks.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's meat and sustenance there, but Cherry Blossoms too often traffics in shopworn Western notions of Japanese culture; it's a pilgrim's-eye-view of Zen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's a grace to it all, and moments of oddball poetry will reward patient viewers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie's conceits are just barely endurable, but the sharpness of Dorrie's eye -- for Tokyo's electric night, for Fuji's iconographic landscapes, for cherry blossoms -- sustains emotion even when story logic fails.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Refusing to be rushed, Doris Dorrie blends individual experiences with universal emotions to create a quietly moving study of self-discovery.

item.label: rotten
item.content: At more than two hours, Cherry Blossoms could do with some pruning.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Doris Dorrie's Cherry Blossoms is both a tender tale of cultural crossings and a double portrait of grief.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Rob Marshall's film of Chicago isn't just the most explosively entertaining movie musical in a couple of decades. It's going to be the most influential.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With few respites, Marshall keeps the energy humming, and his edits, unlike those in Moulin Rouge, are crisp and purposeful without overdoing it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Overall, Chicago earns that highest of praises -- I can't wait to see it again.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chicago is everything a musical is supposed to be, with good songs sung by people who sing well, and with lots of sexy dances featuring women who are gorgeous and men who don't get in the way.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: The complications have the appeal of a classic farce, and if the movie's humor requires a suspension of disbelief, the actors are terrific, and there's much pleasure in watching the way the drama redoubles and resolves.

item.label: fresh
item.content: City Island scrapes by and delivers a smile or two because it does contain a fundamental understanding of the rot that sets in when people hide their true selves from the ones they love.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie's comic machinery never stops clanking long enough for us to relax and genuinely enjoy the silliness. But the actors are enjoying themselves, and that goes a very long way.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Garcia and Margulies, who worked so well together in George Hickenlooper's Man from Elysian Fields, show a sure feel for comedy here...

item.label: fresh
item.content: Feeble but well-stuffed comedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I was won over by this movie's affectionate, silly spirit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [It] won't put [Garcia] back on the main road, but he tries some new things in it, and it's fun to watch him work.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Only someone with slow-drying cement in their veins wouldn't be moved.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With its themes of selflessness and grace, as well as its graceful intertwining of comedy and pathos, this is a fine time for a revisit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The British comic is still the consummate pantomimist, unquestionably one of the greatest the stage or screen has ever known.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A beautiful example of Chaplin's ability to turn narrative fragments into emotional wholes. The two halves of the film are sentiment and slapstick. They are not blended but woven into a pattern as eccentric as it is sublime.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Plenty of great moments, and the occasional comic use of sound.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A film worked out with admirable artistry.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Contains some of Chaplin's great comic sequences.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's an altogether wonderful gem, and one of the five best films the silent era has to offer.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Strains to achieve the enchantingly sublime, but ends up sinking to the depressingly ridiculous.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As a remake it's not as poetic as Wenders' masterpiece Wings of Desire, but it's supremely mounted (by ace lenser John Seale) and contains touching performances from Nicolas Cage and Meg Ryan deviating from their respective screen images.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Funnier than Wenders' version, and it also succeeds in visualising LA as a magical city while dealing intelligently with the themes of mortality, sacrifice, free will, and the mixed blessings of the human condition.

item.label: fresh
item.content: My face had been locked in that goofy, awestruck expression you experience only in Spielberg movies. City of Angels demonstrates the best kind of emotionally manipulative filmmaking.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A lovely oddity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It manages to leave a pleasant afterglow for those in the mood for its kind of loving.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie has its affecting moments, but the drearily inevitable has come true -- an original and rather haunting poetic conception has been turned into a literal-minded love story.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An old-fashioned, big-hearted movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: City of Angels is more romantic than profound, but Dana Stevens' script is thoughtful and intelligent, and I never felt insulted by what the characters say, do, or think.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Awash in angelic choruses and panoramic scenery, the movie aspires toward a solemnity that Dana Stevens's prosaic psychobabbling screenplay cannot support.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although City of Angels sometimes dances perilously close to the line between romance and schmaltz, it never crosses it, a nifty maneuver when you consider that the story deals with both love and spirituality, two areas land-mined with cant.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As angel movies go, this is one of the better ones, not least because Meg Ryan is so sunny and persuasive as a heart surgeon who falls in love with an angel.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's an unfortunate end to a promising movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ultimately, it didn't move me in any way.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Even if it occasionally goes off course, City of Ember provides audiences with a thought-provoking and family-friendly adventure.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A thrilling adventure tale and teen fantasy that is grounded in real concerns about who is managing the planet.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though City of Ember is a bit hurried in execution, this first live-action film by director Gil Kenan has the subterranean feel of a dream being described.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The story, based on Jeanne Duprau's novel of the same name, is beautifully constructed. It builds until it reaches the point that it's one edge-of-your-seat moment after another.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Except for watching Bill Murray get attacked by a giant mole (something unique in Billy boy's career so far) this sci-fi fantasy aimed at kids feels wan and warmed over.

item.label: fresh
item.content: City of Ember has almost anything one could want from a science fiction-based family adventure film: likeable characters, an imaginative setting, and a fast pace.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Both light entertainment and smart, subversive literature, urging the young to think for themselves, question authority and make their own destiny.

item.label: fresh
item.content: And though the film ultimately falls short of its considerable promise, there's more than enough here to keep thoughtful moviegoers - of any age - intrigued.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Splendidly cast, intelligent, graphically inventive romp.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's shockingly little plot in this tale of the denizens of the titular city.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A grim fantasy about a cloistered subterranean metropolis that wants to be both a kids' adventure and a dystopian finger-wag. That director Gil Kenan's second feature never quite succeeds as either is a shame for all the dazzling craftsmanship.

item.label: fresh
item.content: City of Ember is one of those sparkling and smart family fantasy films that breed respect for the writers of young adult novels and serve as reminder that good things do come out of Hollywood.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The brightest star is the soundstage that stands in for endangered Ember. It's a beguiling, belching, labyrinthine example of movie magic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [The filmmakers] create a sharply realized and fantastically rich underground city.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A murky, directionless plot sinks this big-budget fantasy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The story's powered by the sense of discovery that moves classic quest tales -- the idea that there's something much, much bigger out there if only you can find it. It's a modest movie that understands the sky's the limit.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While director Gil Kenan and writer Caroline Thompson's work leans heavily toward children's fantasy, their film leaves gaping science-fiction holes.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Like other Irvin films, this noir saga (more of an urban Western) is burdened with a philosophical layer that's incongruous with the basic tale, though acting by Keitel, Dorff, and others is good.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Slight, solemn, borderline silly but watchable.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It is no longer enough that Fellini deal with the ways women tantalize, dominate, and possess his male heroes. Now he must also deal with the women themselves. For Fellini, this is probably not nearly so much fun.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Wonderfully uninhibited.

item.content: Gary Cooper, in a fine, gangly performance as a saintly bootlegger, is worth watching.

item.content: The film was rapturously received as a cinematic equivalent to Jane Austen at the time of its original release.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Claire's Knee is a movie for people who still read good novels, care about good films, and think occasionally.

item.content: Comes very close to being a perfect movie of its kind.

item.content: This is one of those motion pictures where the director (David Dobkin, in his feature debut) and the writer (Matt Healy) are so concerned about developing a clever, serpentine plot that they forget that there has to be a credible ending.

item.label: rotten

item.content: Narrative complexity and momentum make this a true cinematic equivalent of an absorbing page-turner.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's a glimmer of interest in the film's ideological contortions, but as a commercial action thriller this is inflated and sluggish.

item.content: In a film that opens with the sight of a waving American flag, subtlety may not be foremost on anyone's mind. But Mr. Ford's wary intelligence does wonders for a potentially one-dimensional character.

item.content: Varda transforms the typical French cinema gamine into a complex, tragic figure: the girl who's all too good at playing plaything, forced to face the hollowness of her youth.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Not every minute is as spirited as Varda would like us to believe, but in the cinema of enchantment this ranks pretty high.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Generally, Mlle. Varda is so absorbed with her camera stunts, as she is in that scene in the hat shop or when she is screening that comedy short, that the essential concentration on the heroine is neglected and the interest lost.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sad to say, however, the deep-revolving, witty Mankiewicz fails most where most he hoped to succeed. As drama and as cinema, Cleopatra is raddled with flaws. It lacks style both in image and in action.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [A] general muddle.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Cleopatra is not only a supercolossal eye-filler (the unprecedented budget shows in the physical opulence throughout), but it is also a remarkably literate cinematic recreation of an historic epoch.

item.content: It is a surpassing entertainment, one of the great epic films of our day.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: While it's the sadness of the aging geek that resonates most potently throughout Clerks II, the movie itself is far too glib to let anything that bleak get close enough to the surface to bubble over and stain the counter.

item.content: Though it will be of little interest to anyone who has never seen its predecessor, Clerks II should delight Smith's fans.

item.label: fresh

item.content: One of the best American films of the year so far. The filmmakers take what might have been just a gimmicky premise and pursue it meticulously, following wherever it leads. Along the way, they create a shrewd and moving metaphor for the way people live.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This comic fantasy is the best vehicle he's ever had, a high-concept goof that gradually darkens into an emotional nightmare reminiscent of Capra.

item.content: This rickety Sandler vehicle finds the comedy star steering through a charmless fantasy of self-discovery.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Click is perfectly watchable, sometimes funny, and occasionally even touching. But it will be better when you can see it on DVD and fast-forward through all the crummy stuff.

item.content: With its lurching blend of scatology, sentimentality and sci-fi, the movie is a mess. It's also sexist, bigoted and misanthropic. Of course, those qualities used to be part of the star's charm.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Rarely have I wanted to fast-forward through a movie as much as Click, a treacly and not-funny-enough Adam Sandler comedy about a man who uses a magical remote control to fast-forward through life.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film's overall problem is that it asks thoughtful moviegoers to appreciate its good intentions while ignoring its appeal to the basest of adolescent tastes.

item.content: Despite the don't-look-down Olympian settings, Cliffhanger's spirit is brutal and earthbound. The movie is like one of those computer-designed simulator rides that whip you around until you're dizzy and aching but don't actually take you anywhere.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: A study of the urban dope-dealing culture and its toll on everyone who comes in contact with it, the picture has an insider's feel that is constantly undercut by the filmmaker's impulse to editorialize.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The result is a more sober, mournful and meditative expressionism than you'd expect. That's not to say the film isn't suspenseful, but the director's distaste for the inner city's gun culture is clear to see. Superbly acted.

item.content: Helping make these points is as strong a cast as Lee has yet worked with.

item.content: Finally, what sinks \"Cloud Atlas\" is not the largeness of its ambitions but the lack of skill it displays in terms of writing, directing and acting.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Cloud Atlas\" offers more answers than it does questions, and by the end of its nearly three-hour running time - which flies by surprisingly fast, all things considered - it feels like the most feverishly expensive late-night college bull session ever.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.content: Even Donny Osmond's sparkling teeth seem a little dim compared with the unsullied gleam the movie presents as real life.

item.label: rotten
item.content: College Road Trip is nearly as hellish as taking a long trip with a bus full of karaoke-happy tourists. Actually, that's one of the gags.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The third and best feature of Krzysztof Kieslowski's highly ambitious Three Colors trilogy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Another deft, deeply affecting variation on Krzysztof Kieslowski's recurring theme that people are interconnected in ways they can barely fathom.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Stunningly beautiful, powerfully scored and immaculately performed, the film is virtually flawless, and one of the very greatest cinematic achievements of the last few decades. A masterpiece.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Red succeeds so stirringly that it also bestows some much-needed magic upon its predecessors.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Undaunted by the tremendous emotional and moral valence he has by now invited us to expect, Kieslowski controls the film magnificently, putting to use the shapely formal precision he took an entire career to work out.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Visually and emotionally, this is the director's warmest film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What makes Red watchable is Kieslowski's arresting visual sense.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Red is not a movie by a filmmaker who has run out of ideas, but one by an artist at the height of his powers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In this final installment of a glorious trilogy ... [Kieslowski] has saved his greatest for last.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Scene for scene, Mr. Klimov proves a master of a sort of unreal realism that seeks to get at events terrible beyond comprehension.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: Someone should tell these guys you can't score a touchdown throwing lateral passes.

item.content: There is no I in \"team,\" but there are three in \"idiotic.\" And idiotic more or less describes the appeal of The Comebacks, a so-stupid-it's-funny spoof of inspirational sports dramas.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sports fans (including those with old head injuries) are likely to cheer. The rest of us may just go for the long pass.

item.content: The dialogue in The Comebacks is bereft of lines that trigger even a snicker.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Keep your head down, your expectations low and, maybe, good things will happen. We repeat: Maybe.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: While the sights and the sounds aren't enough to constitute a great movie in and of themselves, they do result in a fascinating document.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Come Back, Africa is a timely and remarkable piece of cinema journalism: a matter-of-fact, horrifying study of life in the black depths of South African society.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What it lacks in dramatic structure, it makes up in pictorial urgency.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Its power comes from the location filming of the township.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: DeMille remains conventional with the motion picture as an art form. The eyes of the onlooker are filled with spectacle. Emotional tug is sometimes lacking.

item.label: rotten

item.content: The point of Compliance, which caused walkouts and shouting matches when it premiered at the Sundance Film Festival, is how we are programmed to do things that go against our natural instincts as long as we believe we have the law on our side.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: Note to would-be financial journalists: No one cares about your personal musings. Not even at Portfolio.

item.content: Here we are, only nine months after the Sex and the City movie, and an obsessive spender with an overstuffed closet -and credit card bills to match- no longer seems quite so cute.

item.content: Countdown to Zero is worthwhile to an extent, if that extent is largely to remind the viewer of certain facts that are easily shunted to the back of one's consciousness.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: This handsomely produced film argues that nukes can be eliminated through enforceable international agreements, just as chemical and biological weapons have been banned.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Smart, swift and scary as hell.

item.label: rotten
item.content: World destruction is no laughing matter, and yet this movie's treatment of it is sometimes amusingly desperate.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Alternately edifying and alarming.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This scarily convincing argument that the end, if not quite nigh, is at least foreseeable urges us to wake up and smell the highly enriched uranium.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Illustrating the many ways nuclear weapons could kill you makes Countdown to Zero one of the most frightening documentaries you'll ever see, or endure.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For a film that traffics in implacable malice, this movie remains remarkably grounded in the everyday.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: What makes the movie a masterpiece, however, is not the Coens' supreme command of their craft in these scenes, but their willingness to embrace the resigned worldview of McCarthy's novel.

item.content: [It] just might be the Coen brothers' singular mythic masterwork.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Working from a Cormac McCarthy novel that has the heedless, headlong force of an action movie screenplay, Joel and Ethan Coen have improved upon the original by giving it a visual lyricism to match McCarthy's verbal barrage.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The story is vintage McCarthy in its sense of place and its poetic voice. And it is vintage Coens for some of those same traits, and its cruel, graphic violence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The Coens are wintry and dead calm ironists, and their movie is finally less an assault on our sensibilities than a subtle -- and possibly permanent -- insinuation into our consciousnesses.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The Coen brothers' screenplay is faithful to McCarthy without being obsequious. In filming it, they play it straight, and the touches of signature humor that are there don't seem like flashes of style, but organic and right.

item.label: fresh
item.content: No Country for Old Men is based on a novel by Cormac McCarthy, but it shows all the Coen strengths. One is a genuine interest in the way people work.

item.label: fresh
item.content: No Country for Old Men is the first movie I've seen in a very long while that deserves to be called a masterpiece. It's such a stunning achievement in storytelling.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: If Feste actually believes that this show is country nirvana, she has no business making a country movie.

item.content: The movie isn't worth the scuffed cowgirl boots it's scooting around in.

item.label: rotten

item.content: Feste struggles mightily to instill meaning and grandeur in Country Strong, but her initial efforts to sidestep cliche often result in confusion before she simply gives up and opts for melodrama.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Country Strong has a bit more to recommend it -- the music most of all -- but it's still a tough slog through emotional swamplands.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's too easy to say that Peter Billingsley shot his eye out with this inept comic trifle, but...well, he shot his eye out.

item.label: rotten

item.content: There are also scenes, the disjointed kind that wander off aimlessly in the vague hope of finding a movie, not to mention a laugh.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.content: To put a point to it, the lavish period costumes, operatic mise-en-scene and ceremonial grandeur of Curse of the Golden Flower clashes fatally with the nuanced nastiness of modern marital discord.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For all the swordplay and martial-arts fisticuffs, Curse is its most delirious as a lavish argument for the soap opera's roots in Greek tragedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This spectacularly decorated movie offers the enjoyment of watching Zhang chronicle the lives of one very nutty family. It also allows Zhang to load every inch of the screen with images so full that you half expect them to collapse under their own weight.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Curse is straightforward and solemn, lacking not for spectacle but for humor and a humanizing touch.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Make no mistake, all is epic, violent, bloody madness once the director hits his stride, and fans of Zhang's work will not want to miss Curse of the Golden Flower. But brush strokes are amiss here.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The melodrama here is of a sort seldom taken seriously outside Shakespeare's tragedies, and the final body count rivals Hamlet in its royal bloodletting.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's big, it's beautiful, and you won't leave the theater feeling cheated, no matter how much of a letdown the finale might be.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If looks were all it took to thrill, this opulent, near-operatic historical pageant would rank with Zhang Yimou's last two epics.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Basically, the movie is soap opera done on a grand opera scale -- more Dynasty than Later Tang Dynasty. The immensity of Zhang's vision is eyepopping. Imagine several football fields worth of shimmering golden chrysanthemums.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's operatic in its feeling and there's a lot going on here. And there's murders and betrayals, and affairs that are illicit, and women on horse-back and great fight scenes.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Curse of the Golden Flower is a watchable soap opera, but its marching-band martial-arts scenes are little more than weakly staged retreads of the ones in Zhang's Hero.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: It's not that Dark Skies is so awful you need to be warned away from it. It's just that it's so bland you might as well find something better to do.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Really the biggest problem with Dark Skies is that Stewart can never quite decide just what story he is telling or whether to focus on this character or that, instead struggling to string together scares regardless of how they fit together overall.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie builds a moderate, if less than monumental, level of spookiness, regardless of your ignorance. It's a workmanlike piece of suspense.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A pretty good buildup to OK payoff without any real surprises en route makes Dark Skies feel just enough above average to make one wish it had one memorable spark of conceptual inspiration up its sleeve.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A smart little chiller, one that can be read as a metaphor for the American family in crisis during tough economic times or merely as a tense exploration of things that go bump in the night.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sci-fi and horror fans know to keep watching the skies - but they won't be missing too much if they decide to skip this.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mostly ... it all ends up feeling like a lost, minor episode of \"The X-Files:\" A little scary, a little silly and catnip for those who want to believe.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Dark Skies is an alien-abduction thriller where the biggest acts of appropriation involve the lifting of plots from other - and often better - films.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Writer-director Scott Stewart doesn't want to play his hand too early. By the time the movie is over, it's easy to see why he kept his cards close to his chest. He's not really holding anything.

item.label: fresh
item.content: By introducing human eccentricities into the cold structure of SF, Carpenter creates a vision of the technological future that is both disillusioned and oddly affirmative in its insistence on the unscientific survival of emotional frailty.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: There are some funny routines here, though Mr. Carpenter doesn't seem to have cared much about integrating or sustaining them.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It fails to deliver the narrative thrill twists its origins would promise.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Like so many recent thrillers of this ilk, many of them in some way exploiting the 'innocence' of childhood -- the dumb and unpleasant Hide and Seek springs to mind -- Dark Water falls apart in the wind-down.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A tasteful but unremitting bummer and yet one more case of an Oscar-winning actress proving that she can still do the kinds of disposable movies big awards are supposedly meant to banish from your resume forever.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Dark Water has more substance and a more interesting look than many horror films, but the familiar elements of the story disappoint.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Working from a premise that's not only thin but transparent, Salles struggles mightily to generate tension in any other way possible.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is an eerie, relentlessly grim, invasive little movie -- a tone poem of despair that seeps into you like the damp.

item.content: A mostly faithful adaptation of a scary little story: A mother and her young daughter, needing to save money as the mother negotiates an unhappy divorce, move into a depressing, dark apartment.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's so lacking in heartfelt frights or cheap scares that the few real hair-raising moments, in the finale, don't pay off.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: Walter Salles' haunted-apartment thriller Dark Water doesn't sink like a stone, but for a movie with such a pedigreed director and a cast headed by Jennifer Connelly, it doesn't exactly float much above mediocrity, either.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: What keeps the film alive and more than a little nerve-wracking are a terrific cast and director Walter Salles, who creates a powerfully oppressive mood that meshes seamlessly with the inner turmoil of troubled mom Dahlia.

item.content: Salles seems too uncomfortable with the fantastic to get full value from the creeps and jumps his camerawork delivers.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Salles] has managed to create a movie that's pretty bleak for a Hollywood -- especially Disney -- thriller.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Dark Water is a murky business indeed, painfully sloooow, absurdly derivative and just plain embarrassing for the wealth of talented people involved in it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In a time when American acting icons like Robert De Niro and Jane Fonda take roles in junk and call it good fun, Connelly shows us how an actor can respect commercial moviemaking and her craft.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Narrowly focused and appropriately claustrophobic, Dark Water creates believability by balancing life's small annoyances with darker, more malignant events.

item.label: fresh

item.content: Let's just say that the dog gets the best lines.

item.content: You're drawn in powerfully as the crew members experience a psychologically maddening cycle of lull and storm.

item.content: Suspenseful when it needs to be and intelligent in its depiction of the horrors of war and the sweaty claustrophobia of submarine life. On occasion, it's even -- pardon the pun -- deep.

item.content: Quite what age group this soft-centered entertainment is aimed at is hard to divine.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ends up making you pine for Lucy's gift of forgetting.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This movie paints itself into a corner from which it cannot emerge without becoming an utter disaster as far as I'm concerned.

item.content: A chick flick for guys, with a pH balance in perfect equilibrium between the crass and the sweet.

item.content: Vast majority of the humor is so grotesquely obvious and crudely presented (in addition to being mildly crude in and of itself) that Sandler dissenters are guaranteed to remain just where they are.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: It gets one crucial element of comic filmmaking right in a way that few recent comedies have. It's cast, down to the smallest role, with genuinely funny performers, people who understand how to time a joke, deliver a setup, underplay a deadpan glance.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Date Night\" is not exactly \"Scenes From a Marriage,\" and yet, with Carell and Fey delivering both raucous comedy and real characters, \"Date Night\" is surprisingly smart, funny and sweet.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie's stars, Steve Carell and Tina Fey, are exactly what they seem. They're perfect casting in a short, sweet comedy that makes the most of their genial gifts until it loses its sense of proportion.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In Date Night, Carell is the cake batter that holds up Fey's icing.

item.label: rotten

item.content: Director Brian Robbins keeps going for easy laughs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Eddie Murphy -- was that Oscar nominated performance in Dreamgirls just something I imagined? -- continues to trash his very real talent with bottomfeeding material.

item.content: It's not all that funny.

item.content: There are some laughs here and there, but this is badly edited hack work.

item.content: Really sordid stuff that becomes ridiculous, painful, unbelievable and tedious.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The kind of movie where you ask people how they liked it, and they say, 'Well, it was well made,' and then they wince.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Watching Ringers is not unlike watching a critical operation -- unnerving but also enthralling.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: An intense psychological drama which confronts [Cronenberg's] familiar preoccupations -- fear of physical and mental disintegration, mortality, the power struggle between the sexes -- without the paradoxical protection of visceral disgust.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Wan and Whannell have a carnivalesque sense of fun and a sure instinct for recycling classic horror tropes, but their characters are so flat and their plotting so listless that this low-budget feature fails to generate much suspense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's affectionately done, but rather pointless.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Terrified of puppets? Enjoy being scared? Then you'll be half-satisfied with Dead Silence, a rote horror pantomime.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Dolls are innately unnerving, but the movie's semi-menacing Charlie McCarthys never live up to their potential.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Armed with a decent budget, director James Wan and co-screenwriter Leigh Wannell fashion at least a dozen sequences that are spooky even while they defy logic.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movies have always asked us to suspend our disbelief, but Dead Silence demands our ignorance of its own derivations. A conflation of the horror genre's laziest tropes, plot angles and shorthands.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Formulaic and rather lazy exercise in booga-booga scare tactics.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie's uninteresting characters, boneheaded dialogue and flagrantly nonsensical narrative detract considerably from the virtues of the visual design.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Director Wan demonstrates that he's equally effective working in a more classical vein, especially with his skillful use of chilling low-key sound effects and silence in several scary sequences.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This new movie is a more credible, less grisly act of filmmaking , but it's a less compelling exercise. It doesn't have the ruthless moral reasoning of the first two Saw pictures, however grotesque and specious that reasoning was.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Saw creators Leigh Whannell and James Wan know scary: all that stuff that heebie-jeebied you when you were a kid. (Or as Entertainment Weekly would say: Dead Silence is awash with atavistic horror tropes.)

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's no attempt at humor in Dead Silence, but the biggest sin in the film is the lack of scares.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film's playfully self-aware touches (like a grand old theater named the Guignol) distract from its leaden pacing, three too many final twists and various behavioral idiocies.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A gothic chiller in which morbid atmospherics and simmering suspense build to an ingenious third-act climax.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a good season for zombies.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Every new zombie movie, however, has to be a little bit different than the one that came before it. Otherwise, it wouldn't be horrifying or much fun.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's almost endearing how little Wirkola disguises his thefts from the gore-fests of Raimi, Peter Jackson and George A. Romero.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gore hounds will enjoy the comic mayhem and picturesque blood splatter on the virgin snow.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The Norwegian Nazi-zombie movie Dead Snow is quite the jolly mountain holiday, pitting a group of medical students against a battalion of undead, unpleasant and unstoppable German soldiers hellbent on ruining a perfectly good Easter vacation.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This splatter film is set in Norway, but rest assured, it sticks with the formula.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Those undead baddies, allegedly flash-frozen since World War II, are kind of unique, but they don't make up for the sense of deja vu one feels watching the rest of Wirkola's bloody vacation-from-hell-athon.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The excessive blood and guts and lack of any true scares results in an absurdly conceived and insanely executed movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It felt formulaic from start to finish.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Despite some dry humor, this is no-frills horror, from the hacked limbs to the gouged eyes.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Director] Wirkola keeps the narrative taut, wasting not a frame; and he throws in funny moments, one involving a Nazi's icky intestine. Matt Weston's cinematography adds to the twisted charm.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chomp-chomp, zip-zip go the Nazi zombies in Dead Snow, a self-consciously outlandish horror flick.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If you're in the mood for splatter, well, any film in which someone avoids a nasty fall by grabbing not a rope but a slowly unwinding intestine is certainly in the mood to deliver it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If you tamp down your expectations there is a storm of scary fun to be had in this Scandinavian splatterfest.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Maybe it's silly to criticize a zombie movie for having that not-so-fresh feeling. Then again, you expect more from Nazi flesh-eaters who want their gold back.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The result piles on relentless thrills and unimaginable horrors, with a shock ending guaranteed to make you scream out loud.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An intensely moving and disturbing experience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. Couturie, the director, and his associates have done a first-rate job.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What Couturie and his researchers have done is amazing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The first film about Vietnam to come to us free of bias, free of rhetoric.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The missives get you where you live.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It unfortunately has an unfinished quality, and plays very much like a good first draft for a much better movie than the one on view.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Together, these characters discover the ideas of faith and fellowship as the film congratulates itself on its noble instincts.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A goofy, goodwill gesture toward the U.S. Postal Service, it's never funny and moves slower than an unaddressed letter without postage.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As trite as the framework is, Dear God might have been a charming holiday film, if only its miracles weren't so trite.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Awkward cuts rob the film of cohesion, and even the charming Kinnear seems to disappear at times amid the chaos -- a real test of viewers' faith.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Though aspiring to Capraesque whimsy, Dear God feels and looks like a faded rerun of Marshall's Happy Days.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A sickeningly bad pastiche of much better pictures.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It is a limp, lifeless story starring Greg Kinnear as a con man who becomes a do-gooder, and one of its many problems is that he was a lot more entertaining as a con man.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's like a bad soap opera.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A sucker for a cheap sob, it left me cold.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Halfway through the movie, I decided a better title for this weepie contraption would be The Hurt Letter. Tatum is stolid and semi-expressive, Seyfried widens her eyes to saucer-size.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sometimes the leads pull off genuine tenderness, and other times their gauzily written caricatures can't elevate such overwrought housewife bait, but chances are, given its literary pedigree, most viewers are preordained to love or loathe it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I just did not get pulled in.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Dear John carefully distills selected elements of human experience and reduces them to a sweet and digestible syrup. It may not be strong medicine, but it delivers an effective, pleasing dose of pure sentiment and vicarious heartache.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There is not much point throwing Channing Tatum and Amanda Seyfried into a movie together if they can't devote every waking minute to making out.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Lasse Hallstrom directs with a softness that makes even combat look tranquil.

item.label: rotten
item.content: C'mon, it's the millennium, it's the electronic age, where soldiers everywhere fight with one finger on the trigger of their gun and the other on the send button of their cell phone.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What you end up with is indeed a big pile of goop.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Dear John: I'm in a really sappy movie based on a Nicholas Sparks novel, can you please help me!!!???\"

item.label: fresh
item.content: Dear John succeeds where Sparks duds like Rodanthe crumbled because it harnesses fresher talents to pull off a comforting tale about the enduring power of love.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even Seyfried, who otherwise makes a credible love interest, couldn't convince me -- or, by the sound of the audience's nervous laughter, anyone else in the theater -- that she had to do what she did.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The uneasy combination of the World Trade Center, Sparks and schmaltzmeister director Lasse Hallstrom pushed me perilously close to nausea and diabetic shock, not to mention deep sleep.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Seyfried's performance is lovely. Her character may be sweet, but she's also marvelously direct, two qualities that Seyfried holds in balance perfectly.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Though Ms. Seyfried is a lovely actress, her inexperience shows in her climactic scenes, which aren't written very well to begin with, while Mr. Tatum's stolid reserve decays into dull passivity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Polanski certainly gets the maximum voltage and precision out of his story and actors, keeping us preternaturally alert to shifting power relationships and delayed revelations.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Kingsley shrewdly tantalizes the viewer about his identity, and gets to deliver the text's most riveting monologue at the end. The lesser-known Wilson may be the first among equals, impressing strongly as the equivocating husband.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Polanski wisely never opens out the action from the remote clifftop house. In keeping things claustrophobic, close-up and ambivalent, he heightens the suspense (not to mention the sexual tension).

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. Polanski treads lightly on the clumsier lines, and sustains tension by creating an elegant, unobtrusive dance with the camera.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Death and the Maiden forces the audience to confront questions about torture and punishment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Polanski keeps the situation ambiguous to provoke questions of guilt and responsibility.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Any degree of tension cultivated by Polanski is frequently undermined by Rafael Yglesias and Ariel Dorfman's sputtering script.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Richer than its materials might promise.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The Polanski touch -- apart from a little suspense here and there -- is limited.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The fundamental strength of Weaver's personality doesn't work here. Nor does her particular style of rage and sorrow.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although it still only just gets away with sundry homophobic and size-ist gags, there's a tad more zing than the original, though if you caught that already, be warned: this is a scene-for-scene retread.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I like the cast.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I like this new one mainly because of the cast.

item.label: rotten
item.content: So much sameness, yet so fewer laughs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Think of Death at a Funeral as a comic quickie. As it presses buttons, a few laughs come out, but that's all there is to it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The stellar cast is wasted on scatological humor, running jokes that are run straight into the ground, and corpse-centered slapstick that's less inspired than \"Weekend at Bernie's.\"

item.label: rotten
item.content: If for the most part Death at a Funeral is as tame as the tasteful parlor where most of its action takes place, it manages to explode one taboo, in casting mostly black actors in roles originally played by whites.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's because of a superior cast that this version of Death at a Funeral is the rare comedy remake that's funnier than the original, however slightly. Personally, though, I'm not sure it was worth the effort.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Death at a Funeral does what a good comedy is supposed to do: generate laughter.

item.label: fresh
item.content: LaBute wisely cast comic actors, rather than actors attempting to be comic. Timing and delivery are paramount in comedy, all the more so when the material is as daft as this.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You must really love a movie if you decide to remake it just three years after its release. But unless you also intend to improve upon the first attempt, what's the point?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Loved the slapstick, winced at the toilet humor, and mourned that the female performers were given so little to do.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's logy, clumsy; instead of lifting the viewer up and carrying him or her on constant currents of escalating comic velocity, it lumbers from bit to bit, and the waits for funny stuff can seem endless.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You can get away with almost anything in a farce except failing to be funny, and that's what kills Death at a Funeral.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The only death at this funeral was that of a good movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is the first comedy from Neil LaBute, an acclaimed director of drama, and he doesn't seem to have the hang of it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A mixed bag, Death at a Funeral has moments of real wit -- and moments when you envy the corpse.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Completely unnecessary and sloppier than it should be. It's also still funny, partly thanks to smart casting in a few key roles and partly because farce this ironclad cannot be denied.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Neil LaBute and an all-star cast surprisingly breathe new life into the material.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Nothing in Death Hunt makes a great deal of sense, though the scenery is rugged and the snowscapes beautiful.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Death in the Garden is a kind of halfway house for the film genius, made when he had yet to receive the acclaim that would give him full control of his movies, but after he had been taken seriously enough by the money men.

item.label: fresh
item.content: No masterpiece, but a prime example of subversive cinema.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Visconti's mastery of visual style almost succeeds in creating the very ideas and feelings that his heavy-handed narrative entirely misses.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Instead of bringing the story to life, Visconti has, I'm afraid, embalmed it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Transposes] the ugliness of power relations in a repressive society to the spheres of sex and gossip.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What's missing is shapeliness, suspense, narrative cunning, visual flair -- in short, art. Are we really to believe that a network of the future would broadcast such a barbiturate?

item.label: rotten
item.content: Just as the ducks get lined up in a row and we're ready for the movie to reveal its true purpose -- Political satire? Paranoid dystopian fantasy? Apologia for the Bush administration? -- we suddenly realize it has none.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Every thinking person should see Death of a President.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Death of a President is thought-provoking, but as much for 'how'd they do that?' as for its ideas.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even people who think George W. Bush is the worst American-made disaster since President James Buchanan will have no trouble recognizing Death of a President for the lousy thing it is.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The fact of the Bush years far outdoes Range's dull fiction. The only thing that shook me was the idea of Cheney as president. Now that is the stuff of nightmares.

item.label: rotten
item.content: D.O.A.P. offers no information, insights or ideas that a couple of political science majors couldn't come up with while hanging out between classes.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While it dazzlingly manipulates snippets of film to create a genuine-looking docudrama, its knee-jerk, black-and-white political imagination never equals its technical expertise.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Aside from satisfying some kind of ghoulish curiosity about how such an incident could possibly happen, there's precious little in Death of a President to justify the extremity of its central conceit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Death of a President is a masterly piece of documentary chicanery that kills George W. Bush without once pandering to his legions of ill-wishers.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Death of a President manages to be predictable and astounding at the same time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: To the credit of Range and Simon Finch, with whom he wrote the screenplay, it makes its point and poses its moral questions without speeches or quotation marks.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I won't tell you how the story resolves the question of who killed the president. I will tell you that it involves a careless reading of American society by a director who apparently hasn't totally thought through what he's saying.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's a cowardice at work here. Playing with the powerful tools of documentary, it poses as artistically courageous when it's often little more than a muddied if familiar meditation on the sorry state of affairs the U.S. finds itself in in Iraq.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I give nothing away by telling you the president dies. From that point on, the film's most egregious offense is becoming predictable and heavy-handed.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [DOAP] wants to function as a mindless thriller that eventually makes us think -- and only after the film is over question the form that encouraged us to be mindless. These are incompatible agendas, and in the end neither is fully successful.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The whole film has the whiff of a low-cost documentary unspooling on a basic cable channel on Sunday afternoon when you should be out raking leaves.

item.label: rotten
item.content: And the point is ... what, exactly?

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's brainless fun, but while Anderson's brilliant staging of the flesh-ripping stunts surpasses Bartel's cheap thrills, this update lacks the sardonic wit and satirical bite of the Corman-produced version.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Let Death Race serve as a warning, or maybe an inspiration, to any TV producer who says she'd kill for high ratings: Why not stage a pay-per-view car race in which prisoners compete to stay alive on the course?

item.label: rotten
item.content: The combination of good actors and terrible dialogue might have allowed the film a chance at minor cult status, if it weren't for the frustratingly inept action sequences.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Death Race is cartoonishly brutal and pleasantly disreputable.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Statham's films never promise to be something they're not or offer something they don't provide. Death Race is not an exception.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like first love -- or maybe just a crowbar to the Adam's apple -- Death Race works fast and hits hard. A prison flick and a car chase movie at the same time? I am so there.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Well, you've got to say this for Death Race: It knows what it is and doesn't apologize for it. What it is, incidentally, is junk.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Car-crash porn for the modern audience.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It has the tough guy lead, dozens of mad car crack-ups, tons of gratuitous violence, sweaty B-movie appeal, and even a couple of A-talent actors, but in the end Death Race runs around in circles.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie gets its own Mad Max mojo working, but there's no real attempt at social commentary here -- these churls just want to have fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is still summer trash and no brain cells were injured or even fatigued in the making of it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Actors try to add a touch of class to a picture that's utterly crass.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Yes, Death Race is as brutal as a punch in the face. If you have a hankering for B-movie grime and gore, it can also be a lot of fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It is an assault on all the senses, including common. Walking out, I had the impression I had just seen the video game and was still waiting for the movie.

item.content: No fancy talk here, just solid, monosyllabic obscenities; no flights of digital fancy, just souped-up monster cars flipping end over end in a napalm blaze and crashing in a crunch of flaming metal ouch.

item.content: This graphically violent film suffers from cursorily developed characters whose primary function is to advance the creaky plot.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The morality of revenge is barely at issue in a movie that pushes the plausibility of revenge right over a cliff.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's terrible and it's so disappointing because I love Kevin Bacon and I love Aisha [Tyler] and you have good actors here who are trapped.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The result is such a mish-mash of conflicting tones and ideas that it doesn't play well on any level.

item.label: rotten
item.content: . At both its best and worst, it feels like the missing third part of the faux retro double-bill Grindhouse.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As rancid as its title is lurid, an example of pulp fiction run amok.
