item.content: Blunt, bloody and far too busy with its sledgehammer plot and mighty gunplay to waste time on the main character's inner life, Death Sentence is a baseline entertainment.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If only the world were a more peaceful place, we wouldn't have to sit through movies like Death Sentence.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Fails to provide any sort of genuine social context for its violence.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Bacon's performance in Saw creator James Wan's laughably extreme revenge thriller Death Sentence is six degrees of ham.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An old-school exploitation picture, polished off with a modern sensibility by Saw director James Wan.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It may be the most depressing action movie ever made. Its calamities are well staged, and its acting, beyond some histrionics, is fine. But you don't enjoy this film; you endure it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Both the story and (literal) execution here are cheap and somewhat embarrassing for Bacon and company. Kill this movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Is the movie trying to show how bloodlust and revenge can destroy a person? If so, it simultaneously revels in violence. Trying to have it both ways diminishes the entire undertaking, rendering it despicably hypocritical.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Death Sentence has a crude, naturalistic style that fails to disguise the fact that its twists and turns become increasingly preposterous.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A dark comedy that blows up like an exploding cigar, leaving nothing much behind but smoke, noise and a bad taste.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: I'm sure that some country, maybe France or something, will hail this as a work of genius, because it is so incredibly awful.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A blacker than black comedy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is a particularly toxic little bonbon, palatable to only a chosen and very jaundiced few.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An annoying, strident misfire.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's so much that's just right in Danny DeVito's dark, behind-the-scenes satire of children's television that it's frustrating -- and a bit puzzling -- that the film doesn't quite work overall.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In Death to Smoochy, we don't get Williams' usual tear and a smile, just sneers and bile, and the spectacle is nothing short of refreshing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This kind of dark comedy requires a delicate, surgical touch. But director Danny DeVito and screenwriter Adam Resnick (remember Cabin Boy?) just pound away.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The cynicism is colossal, the casting superb: Norton may be the only actor alive who could pull off a character like Sherman, without making him either an idiot or a parody.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The cinematic equivalent of being poked in the ribs with a fork for two hours, this relentlessly irritating comedy redefines the term 'over the top' -- and we don't mean that as a compliment.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The comedy Death to Smoochy is a rancorous curiosity: a movie without an apparent audience.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Loud, obscene, obvious and endlessly, assaultively repetitive, Death to Smoochy stands as a classic case of a bad thing happening to good actors.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For all its calculated cruelties, Death to Smoochy never gets as down and dirty.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is the kind of stinker that emerges every so often from Hollywood when major 'talent' -- Danny DeVito and Robin Williams, in this case -- get it into their heads that something disastrously unfunny is hilarious.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Poisonous incitement to do-it-yourself law enforcement is the vulgar exploitation hook on which Death Wish is awkwardly hung.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Winner's recourse to caricature when dealing with police and thugs, and his virtually overt sympathies with the confused, violent Bronson, make for uncritical, simplistic viewing.

item.label: rotten

item.content: Willis' John McClane, with that sly, sideways smile, is like an old acquaintance you don't mind running into. He may be older and balder, but he's none the worse for the wear. And he can still take a punch.

item.content: This might go down as the year that science-fiction cinema, despite the deafening crash and clangor of sparring robots, began to rediscover its brains, heart and soul.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a cool little thriller with some big scares and fine performances.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Closing on a surprisingly prudish, prosurveillance note, you don't have to wonder if lessons have been learned. Downloaded, maybe. Not learned.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Offsetting the chilly voyeurism is a viable teen romance and an appealing sense of humor. Though there are occasional lapses in logic, Disturbia is consistently suspenseful and entertainingly disturbing.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Caruso, a very visual director, serves up some surprises and scares, and he's paced his movie briskly. You're out of this disturbing suburbia before you know it, shaken and even stirred.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A surprisingly competent film, Disturbia lives up to its title. It's rare to find a decent film turn up in the dead of April, traditionally Hollywood's dump month for shelved oddities.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Director D.J. Caruso relies entirely too much on cliched shock cuts and keeps pulling back every time the flick seems to be settling into anything close to a creepy mood.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What Disturbia lacks in complexity, it makes up for in witty jokes, sneaky jolts and a timeless lesson: If you've got windows, someone's always watching.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Despite the foolishness, and despite the patent knockoffs of Rear Window and American Beauty, Disturbia is a likable little thriller.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Reasonably smart and sometimes funny -- right up until the end, when it sells out its intelligence in favor of a standard-issue dose of overwrought violence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Disturbia will have young people on the edge of their seat, cringing and thinking at the same time.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Instead of manufacturing elaborate, ridiculous plot twists or imposing overwrought psychological melodrama on a basically absurd premise [director] Caruso and the screenwriters opt for efficient, clever B-movie execution.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The most disturbious part of Disturbia is how engaging this teenage thriller manages to be, even though it's a shameless rip-off of Rear Window.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: It plays like a salvage job, with all the attendant compromises. Though the film is laden with backstory and exposition, not much actually happens onscreen.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus is vintage Terry Gilliam, a pour not to all tastes but one certain to please lovers of Time Bandits and The Adventures of Baron Munchausen.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mainstream audiences will probably be confounded by \"Drive,\" while lovers of gritty filmmaking will defend every exaggerated shotgun wound as art. Know which camp you're in before you enter the theater.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The first half of Drive unfolds like a romantic reverie.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: Despite nifty F/X, first-time director Ellory Elkayem's staging is altogether devoid of variation.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [I]ts marginally amusing, but I'm giving it thumbs down.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is a poster movie, a mediocre tribute to films like Them!

item.label: fresh
item.content: As green-guts monster movies go, it's a beaut.

item.label: rotten
item.content: However many screaming teenagers it produces at the multiplexes, Eight Legged Freaks isn't good or funny enough to reinvigorate the style. It can't even maintain its own initial zing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Like many of the worst pop-referential parodies of the post-Scream era, this one stalls on laughs once the big joke has been established.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: Neither as scary-funny as Tremors nor demented-funny as Starship Troopers, the movie isn't tough to take as long as you've paid a matinee price.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Not scary enough to work as a straight-up horror flick and nowhere near funny enough to be a passable spoof.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Eight Legged Freaks limps along, spinning not a silken web but an extremely derivative, tattered one not likely to snare anybody's interest.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Good for a quick adrenaline surge -- until the next horror fix comes along.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sayles often seems like a man who, trying to stretch a single, gets caught between bases and is desperately trying to evade the rundown.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: Baseball fans might find this marginally absorbing; for anyone else it's as conscientious and stylistically pedestrian as Sayles's other films, and a mite overlong to boot.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Given the inevitably knotty plotting, the message is oddly unrevealing, although the film features more than enough intelligently, wittily scripted moments to remain a fascinating insight into a crucial episode in the souring of that old American Dream.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For Mr. Sayles, whose idealism has never been more affecting or apparent than it is in this story of boyish enthusiam gone bad in an all too grown-up world, Eight Men Out represents a home run.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's an insider's movie, a baseball expert's film that is hard for the untutored to follow.

item.label: rotten

item.content: Call me Scrooge, but I sincerely hope that this film does not become a Christmas perennial.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Garner has no trouble looking sexy, and teen boys should enjoy Elektra's many gratuitous costume changes, but she's hopelessly unconvincing in this icy role.

item.content: Hmmm, where have I seen this before? Oh, yes, I saw it Wednesday night on television. Except her hair was pink. And I had eight more bucks in my wallet.

item.content: Elektra the movie is a lot like Elektra the assassin. It executes its mission with considerable precision but never feels truly alive.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.content: Unfortunately, the script that John Lee Mahin prepared from the Robert Standish book is lengthy and hackneyed in the build-up, and William Dieterle's direction does not provide anything more than gaudy panoramas of a tropical palace to fascinate the eye.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Henri Decae's black-and-white cinematography brings out the melancholy mystery of Paris' boulevards and cafes, and Ms. Moreau, shot with natural lighting and without make-up, is like a mournful goddess of glamour.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The plot crackles with energy and misdirection, while the black-and-white film sharpens angles and amplifies the shadows lurking in every hallway.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie's most compelling element of all is Moreau, wandering the nighttime streets trying to find her lover. It's as if she's blown from one cafe to the next on a blended wind of passion, dread and the lonely trumpet wail.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As French crime thrillers go, this is about as good as it gets. It's also an important film historically, and to top it off, the jazz score, by Miles Davis, is famous in its own right.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Don't miss this opportunity to see the movie that launched the legend of Jeanne Moreau.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moreau's nocturnal wanderings are made unbearably poignant by an exquisite Miles Davis jazz score that became famous in its own right.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's precisely Malle's omnivorous appetite that makes his first feature, adapted from a policier, so delectable, one stuffed with many sumptuous sights and sounds.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: A movie made by people who really have their thinking caps on.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ferrell's stone-stupid sincerity keeps the action moving and irresistible, despite its familiarity.

item.content: Thanks to Ferrell, it's a tolerably sweet holiday treat.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: As an original family film for the holidays, it's fresh, timely and quite funny.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Say hello, kiddies, to the first big-hearted flick of the season. Time's up, so say goodbye and, be polite now, try to hide your mild disappointment.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: The danger in making a costume drama is that all of it will be as lifeless as wax figures. Kapur escapes this fate by relying on sex and a luminous star capable of being at once regal and alluring.

item.content: Every time the camera finally settles on Blanchett's regal cheekbones, it's a relief.

item.label: rotten

item.content: What Elizabeth: The Golden Age finally lacks is something its subject never lacked: a sense of majesty.

item.content: It's confusing and excessive and it just missed the mark completely.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If it sounds as though the script (credited to Ehren Kruger, Robert Orci, and Alex Kurtzman) was written in serial-novel form during an all-night mescaline bender, well, I have no evidence that it was not.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I saw Revenge of the Fallen at Imax, which is probably why I managed to stay awake in what for me was the world's most boring movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The special effects are better and the dialogue slightly more humorous than in the first movie, but the anti-Arab subtext is repugnant.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Transformers: The Revenge of The Fallen is beyond bad, it carves out its own category of godawfulness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The right notes are struck over and over for the target demo but there's not much for the rest of us. The special effects are no longer quite so special. A fact that doesn't stop Bay from committing more-is-less excesses.

item.label: fresh
item.content: By the climactic desert conflict, in which the entire Valley of the Kings is razed, the film has become so breathtakingly, boneheadedly brazen that it's easier just to give in.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Compared to this sequel, the first Transformers, which was released two years ago, ranks right up there with Kant's Critique of Pure Reason.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Though battles are Transformers' raison d'etre, before it's over, Revenge will collapse under the weight of far too many of them.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Bay seems to think that just showing us a bunch of brightly clashing metallic limbs (accompanied by lots of noise) is enough to make us faint in our seats with excitement.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The simplest thing Bay could have done to clarify the stakes of the robot wars would be to visually distinguish the robots from one another in some way. Armbands? Shirts and skins? \"Hello, My Name Is\" stickers?

item.label: fresh
item.content: A well-oiled, loudly revving summer action vehicle that does all that's required, and then some.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What's wrong here is that there's so much swirling, relentless action, indistinct robot characterizations and over-caffeinated techies loose on the special-effects machines that the movie, in mere seconds, achieves incoherence.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The best thing about \"Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen\" is that it's perhaps the funniest movie of the year ... \"Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen\" is not as bad as \"Transformers\"; somehow, in the face of long odds, it is actually worse.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An exhilarating rush of a movie, with all manner of go-for-broke visual bravura that expresses perfectly the free spirits of [Wong's] bold young people.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Wong brings tremendous vigor and audacity to the effort, asking us to question the most basic rules of storytelling and commercial filmmaking.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A densely packed suite of zany vignettes that have the autonomy of pop songs or stand-up comic riffs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Let's face it, there is an element of truth in the character of D-FENS. But it is, finally, tabloid truth.

item.label: fresh
item.content: At first comes across like a mean-spirited black comedy and then snowballs into a reasonably powerful portrait of social alienation. The tone is unremittingly dour, however.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A real artist could make something incisive or darkly hilarious out of this moral tightrope act. Schumacher, veering recklessly between social satire, kick-ass fantasy and damsel-in-distress melodrama, plays the game for opportunistic cheap thrills.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sometimes funny, sometimes touching, and certainly unnerving.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It turns one man's slide toward madness into a wickedly mischievous, entertaining suspense thriller.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Douglas's intentionally robotic -- and intense -- performance holds its own. He's scary, normal and funny all at once...

item.label: rotten
item.content: Unfortunately, it continues on through an uninspired series of cartoonishly brutal social insults, each one growing more lethal than the next, thereby justifying an increasingly lethal response.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film ... is actually about a great sadness which turns into madness, and which can afflict anyone who is told, after many years of hard work, that he is unnecessary and irrelevant.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although it takes a number of wrong turns, Falling Down still has the power to disturb.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Falling Down is a brutally manipulative revenge fantasy, a piece of comic-strip demagoguery that teeters uneasily on the brink of satire.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The high school is so sanitized that there are no drugs, cutthroat competition, or-inconceivably for a theatrical milieu-no gay students.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There are enough hoary soap-operatic plottings for a thousand Gossip Girls (emotionally distant parents, almost-rapes, suicide attempts), yet Tancharoen individualizes each crisis so that no one character comes off as a mock-universal surrogate.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I don't mind the cornball and I don't mind the cliches, but I just think that the thing has to be executed a little better than this.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's almost fatally modest. But it has a sweet spirit, and it offers only one true moment of inadvertent camp: a (lame) finale featuring an African dance routine completely at odds with all the white bread we've just been served.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The production numbers are great, sometimes jaw-droppingly so.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This film makes even the most gaudy of Saturday night TV talent contests look like Dostoyevsky in comparison.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A desperate, cynical -- and most likely unsuccessful -- attempt by a dying studio to stave off oblivion by jumping on the High School Musical bandwagon, exploiting one of its legacy titles in ways that dishonor the original.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Already?\" the woman behind me said plaintively when the words \"Sophomore Year\" flashed up on the screen. That's the joy of this Fame. Like the old ones, it convinces you that high school, if not life, should go on forever.

item.label: rotten
item.content: That fame seems assured to those who merely crave it -- without sacrifice, or spiritual and physical effort -- emerges as the underlying message in this sanitized and unrewarding production. Simon Cowell has much to answer for.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The picture is fitfully effective, but the story disappears in the editing bay. The movie has about as much heft as watching jesters and fire eaters at a village fair.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Fame offers slick entertainment with some exuberance, but it's devoid of soul or heart.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Pleasant, undemanding entertainment for drama-club kids and the people who love them -- a family-friendly salute to young performing artists.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A big, bland and bogus clone of a movie update, which runs a half-hour less than the original and only feels like forever.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Its] hyperreal documentary quality is combined with a borderline fantasy feeling, which will probably drive some literal-minded viewers up the wall, but which is actually the movie's best element and its one claim to distinction.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Suffers from a surfeit of flash, it nonetheless offers the undeniable power of young performers pursuing art at peak dexterity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Hitchcock has a deviously complicated tale to tell, and he's going to tell it with labyrinthine detail, and he's not going to cheat.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A witty, relaxed lark.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Buoyed by infectious high spirits and self-deprecating humour, the film works in strange and perhaps unintentional ways, thanks largely to the sustained energy of the lead actors, and writers Ernest Cline and Adam F. Goldberg.

item.content: Turns out there is something more annoying than an infatuated bunch of Star Wars nerds. Turns out a movie about an infatuated bunch of Star Wars nerds can really set your teeth on edge.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It was a great premise, it just unfortunately did not come together.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A lot of promise here, no execution.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Fanboys is pretty much for fanboys.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Genial and potty-mouthed and dumb and sweet -- a rudely engaging road comedy with more inside Star Wars baseball than a convention hall full of Imperial Grand Moffs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A few laughs here and there and a couple of moments of emotionally stunted sweetness add up to a Fanboys that only a fanboy would love.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Fanboys doesn't delve into the mania of fandom, it exploits it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is not the film you're looking for.

item.content: You'd think the weakest link in Fanboys would be that it's all in-jokes, but they're actually not so 'in' that a casual fan won't get them.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Though it does feature a few inspired comic moments, there is a surplus of tired, overused gags.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Uninspired and only faintly funny.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Unfortunately, the filmmakers forget that the most important part of an in-joke is the joke.

item.label: rotten
item.content: At this point, Lucas is in no position to be picky about his remaining fans.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's not nearly nerdy enough.

item.content: Even geeks enjoy poking fun at geeks. And they really know how.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An adorable, preposterous mutant film from the heyday of international do-your-own-thing moviemania.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: It wanders sadly through routine action sequences, mixing slapstick with derring-do yet never generating any wit or romance.

item.content: Sumptuous, haunting, and unusually tender... a nakedly psychological 'in' to [Bergman's] earliest artistic impulses; nothing else in his oeuvre addresses so directly his childhood escapes into fantasy as the by-product of a harsh Lutheran upbringing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Our young protagonist will be obsessed with death and see ghosts everywhere. Never has the prison of childhood seemed so inescapable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The result is one of Bergman's most haunting and suggestive films.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A sumptuously produced period piece that is also a rich tapestry of childhood memoirs and moods, fear and fancy, employing all the manners and means of the best of cinematic theatrical from high and low comedy to darkest tragedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a marvellously engrossing and thought-provoking film, filled with dazzling dramatic set-pieces and witty, knowing allusions to its creator's artistic conceits and deceits.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Utterly enthralling.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A fitting introduction to the very personal cinema of this master craftsman, not only because it exhibits Bergman's signature themes and stylistic devices, but also because it is one of his most life-affirming films.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Bergman] glides beyond the mere telling of his story into a kind of hypnotic series of events that have the clarity and fascination of dreams. Rarely have I felt so strongly during a movie that my mind had been shifted into a different kind of reality.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It is very much, and in the best way, an old man's movie, the work of an artist resigned to life's mystery, full of wonder at the passage of time, full of forgiveness for past wrongs, and full of understanding.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A big, dark, beautiful, generous family chronicle, which touches on many of the themes from earlier films while introducing something that, in Bergman, might pass for serenity.

item.content: The words most used to describe \"Fantasia,\" besides the conventional \"beautiful\" and \"wonderful\" were \"path-breaking\" and \"courageous.\" The phrase \"courageous beyond belief\" would be even more accurate.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Critics may deplore Disney's lapses of taste, but he trips, Mickey-like, into an art form that immortals from Aeschylus to Richard Wagner have always dreamed of.

item.content: There is something in Fantasia for every taste.

item.content: The concept and some of the episodes are tainted with kitsch, but there's no other animated film with its scope and ambition.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Certainly not to be missed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Fantasia is simply terrific -- as terrific as anything that has ever happened on a screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is animation in every sense of the word, as if you are seeing the world through the eyes of your tree-worshipping ancestors.

item.content: The performances are plywooden, the cornball visual gags are groanworthy, and Tim Story still can't direct his way out a sack with a map.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The first movie's genesis story was more fun than the perfunctory doomsday scheme trotted out here.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you swept the cosmic dust of the superhero boom into a flimsy dustpan, you'd have the Fantastic Four franchise.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer is more ambitious than its predecessor. It's also more cluttered and less fleet: The light, pleasingly casual quality of the first picture has evolved into something forced and metallic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer is a vast and significant improvement -- if not quite \"fantastic,\" then the next best thing: It does not suck.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Compared with its predecessor, the new movie contains less silliness to offend purists. At the same time, there isn't much to thrill anyone, either.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: In Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer, our heroes get what they deserve: a decent action flick with a jolt of visual wow.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Unlike the recent spate of blackened threequels, those bottom-of-the-bag Spideys and Shreks and Pirates and Oceans, this kernel does pop.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Yes, the too-hot Alba is still miscast, and the film suffers from clumsy moments. But when it soars, it soars, and it is both blessedly brief and bloodless.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You don't walk out of Rise of the Silver Surfer feeling as if you've gone three rounds with the Thing. This is a case where getting less than you bargained for feels like a victory.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The result is not only marvellous whimsy, but also something that advances the burgeoning retro-tech movement.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Anderson injects such charm and wit, such personality and nostalgia -- evident in the old-school animation, storybook settings and pitch-perfect use of Burl Ives -- that it's easy to forgive his self-conscious touches.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Wes Anderson's utterly charming Fantastic Mr. Fox is that rarity: a children's movie for all.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The tale may be Dahl's, but there's a whole new wag to it -- this is decidedly, weirdly and, at best, wonderfully a Wes Anderson movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The result is a quirky film that should work for all ages, with just a hint of dark humor. In this age of high-tech animation, Wes Anderson has found himself in a low-tech wonderland.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like the rest of his movies, this one is essentially infantile -- but when you're telling the story of a ne'er-do-well fox conspiring against a trio of nasty farmers, who cares?

item.label: fresh
item.content: The filmmakers hew to Dahl's intent and add fine turns of their own.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The most fantastic thing about Mr. Fox is the way he shows that while our flaws can bring us down, sometimes, too, we triumph in spite of them and because of them.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Children, especially, will find things they don't understand, and things that scare them. Excellent. A good story for children should suggest a hidden dimension, and that dimension of course is the lifetime still ahead of them.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film earns its title's superlative and a hundred more.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Other filmmakers turn to children's stories when they have kids of their own. Anderson seems to have made this one for his inner child.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film's premise may be child-like, but its themes -- family, self-identity and existential angst -- are all engagingly adult.

item.content: Anderson's stop-motion Fantastic Mr. Fox is both a delightful amusement and a distillation of the filmmaker's essential playfulness.

item.content: An opportunity missed, therefore -- especially as the imaginative sets are slightly tackily realised -- but fun all the same.

item.label: fresh

item.content: The foreboding and chaos contrast neatly with the lavish costumes and sets.

item.label: fresh
item.content: We know what will happen, of course, but Jacquot still manages to create tension, as well as a semi-soap opera, among the let-them-cake-eaters of post-Enlightenment France.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Farewell, My Queen\" is worth a look simply for its look.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The guillotine's blade is, as yet, nowhere to be heard. But you can feel Jacquot's pleasure is slicing and dicing this material in novel ways.

item.content: Jacquot takes a refreshingly understated approach to costume drama, avoiding historical generalizations to focus on the particulars of palace life and the psychological states of individual characters.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Lepage's films are always reflections of a curious mind, which constantly puzzles at the absurdity of a life where science, politics and the arts compete for attention with the mundane existence of daily life.

item.content: [Flags] fits into Eastwood's late-in-life agenda -- to make violence, even in self-defense, seem soul-killing, and to expose the gulf between reality and myth. After this, how can we ever again make our peace with the iconography of war?

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: It tries hard and means well. And I couldn't hardly wait for it to end. Freedomland falls short as entertainment.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's a truly inspiring story; pity the movie doesn't live up to it.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.content: Ghost Town, a romantic comedy about the living and the dead coming to terms with each other, is both very funny and a bit of a tearjerker, with an on-the-money performance from Ricky Gervais and a nice feeling for New York in fall.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Leoni and Gervais are wonderful together, as much for the ways in which they wobble against each other as for the ways they ultimately mesh.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although ghost hijinks are a very Hollywood way of dealing with the subject, the twists are executed superbly, right up to a climax that fits the David Mamet definition of what makes for a perfect ending: It is both surprising and inevitable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Leave it to the unfailingly brilliant Gervais to breathe new life into an expiring genre.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The painfully awkward, stubby Gervais as romantic lead is a funny enough concept, but the actor's ongoing banter with Kinnear is engaging, and their styles mesh entertainingly.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gervais is a master of the flustered broken thought, and Koepp takes full advantage in scenes that pit Pincus against a distracted doctor (a droll Kristen Wiig) and an imposingly large dog.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The sharp comic timing and the offbeat chemistry of Ricky Gervais, Greg Kinnear and TA (C)a Leoni keep Ghost Town afloat.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With lesser talent in front of the camera or a heavier hand behind it, the film might have crashed with a thud.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A mash-up of old-school heroism, pantomime villainy, starstruck lovers and post-'Shrek' archness, it's more exhausting than exhilarating.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's fast, rousing, and blessedly brief - under two hours instead of, say, nine in three bladder-straining installments.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Not awful, not wonderful, Jack the Giant Slayer is a midrange fairy tale epic that's a lot more ho-hum than fee-fi-fo-fum.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jack the Giant Slayer is slight, but consistently amusing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie feels so much like a video game that your fingers instinctively itch to do something, though a Jack video game isn't one we'd really want to play.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The script sets up the situation and characters nicely, and the actors are terrific.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although it often feels there's more of mechanics than the muse keeping Jack the Giant Slayer going, this sprightly fairy tale reworking is full of beans, smartly written and packs plenty of fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While it's fine for a director to explore his childhood inspirations, you hope he would bring something a bit more personal to it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Jack the Giant Slayer\" seems more likely to be \"Jack the Giant Bomb.\"

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Jack\" seems designed to appeal to a very narrow, and possibly illusory, demographic: the mature moppet.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's fast paced, energetic, and enormously likeable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Singer's take on ye olde yarne has wit about it, and it certainly looks good.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There may never have been a Jack tale that delivered so little pleasure for so many dollars as what we have here.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Jack's problem is that he's a commoner, but the movie's problem is that its script is commoner still, an enchantment-free pretext for animated action, straight-ahead storytelling and ersatz romance.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Jack the Giant Slayer\" is the kind of old-fashioned, entertaining fantasy-adventure you once saw regularly in theaters.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's more to this Jack and the Beanstalk adaptation than Fee-fi-fo-fum.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It feels like a film made by a committee, for a demographic rather than an audience. It's a tale full of sound and fury (and flying bodies) signifying nothing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This finally is just a digitally souped-up, one-dimensional take on \"Jack and the Beanstalk,\" capped by the kind of interminable blowout that makes many big-studio entertainments feel as long as the last Oscars.

item.label: fresh
item.content: At its heart, the film is just a simple fairy tale, an epic reduced to an engaging adventure of a bedtime story.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The performances are well nigh faultless.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Gigi is dressed to kill, but if all the French finery impresses the customers, it also smothers the story.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's easy to drift away from the story and become absorbed in Minnelli's impossibly delicate textures, but there is a little something here for everybody.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's like a meal consisting of cheesecake, and one quickly longs for something solid and vulgar to weigh things down.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A charming entertainment.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It ends up being an unfulfilling exercise in pseudo-feminism.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What a blast G.I. Joe: Retaliation is! And then another blast, and another, in a series of concussive jolts that shred any conventional sense of story as thoroughly as anything since the last Michael Bay film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: When it comes to big and loud, this is the movie to beat for at least this week; what makes it entertaining is its unabashed wallow in these qualities ...

item.label: rotten
item.content: Plays like a tiresomely extended evening of channel surfing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: No go, \"Joe.\"

item.label: rotten
item.content: What's the difference between an action figure and an action star? Very little in G.I. Joe: Retaliation, which features no performances of note, even from such combat-tested thespians as Bruce Willis, Jonathan Pryce and Dwayne Johnson.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There should be a \"Fans Only\" sign at the door of every theater.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I won't pretend that I had a great time watching \"G.I. Joe: Retaliation.\"

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ever played a video game with a friend and had to sit there while he hogged it, leaving you to do nothing but watch for what seemed like hours?

item.label: rotten
item.content: Good luck recalling any other would-be set pieces a couple of days after you've seen Retaliation.

item.label: rotten
item.content: People may flock to G.I. Joe: Retaliation despite its inert illogic. But don't say you weren't warned. As a wise man once said, \"knowing is half the battle.\"

item.label: rotten
item.content: To borrow from Jack in the Box, \"G. I. Joe: Retaliation\" is one hot mess.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Unmitigated nonsense to anyone but diehard fans.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Like a Dumpster bin behind Tiffany's, this contains nothing but well-packaged garbage.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A more sure-footed shoot-'em-up that finds some heart, wit and perhaps enough momentum to spawn a formidable action franchise.

item.content: Everything in G.I. Joe: Retaliation is perfunctory - technically proficient but soulless. It's not exciting. It's boring.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's well-executed technocratic action fluff. But it did leave me buzzed rather than drained.

item.label: rotten
item.content: That's not to say that this G.I. Joe is good, aside from a couple of dazzling action set pieces, but at least it's efficient in its muscular mindlessness.

item.content: The G.I. Joe team is back, and most of their sophomore movie adventure, G.I. Joe Retaliation, is as bland as their name and as subtle as an exploding tank.

item.content: [Director] Sommers did the first two chaotic Mummy remakes; those play like Tender Mercies compared to this one.

item.label: rotten
item.content: After a first hour that plays like a bad TV show, Sommers hits his groove with an over-the-top Paris chase sequence that, in turn, leads to an underwater finale that's absurdly overproduced, momentarily diverting, and then instantly forgettable.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's just stupid and inept, which are not uncommon traits at the tail end of the summer movie season.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This pricey, juiceless pulp could never have been killed by critics, simply because it was already dead.

item.label: fresh
item.content: OK, it's seriously deficient in plot or acting. But in this genre, those two ingredients are as superfluous as canoes in a desert.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I could load you up with more plot details, but this mercilessly incoherent, galactically stupid movie left me too numb to type.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's an expectation that the audience will be invested in the relationship between Duke and Ana, but the poor writing and lack of chemistry between the principals fails to sell the romance as anything more substantial than a weak plot element.

item.label: fresh
item.content: G.I. Joe is a loud but proficient slab of explode-o-rama summer blockbuster nonsense, perfectly entertaining if you like that sort of thing, extremely skippable if you don't.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It is sure to be enjoyed by those whose movie appreciation is defined by the ability to discern that moving pictures and sound are being employed to depict violence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Basically, the Joes are not bad, it's just that they could have been much better with a little less conversation, a little more action.

item.label: rotten
item.content: G.I. Joe is like watching fireworks with a blindfold on: it's deafening and you feel under attack.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra is as polished and entertaining as war-mongering toy commercials get.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A movie that's more sci-fi than semper fi -- and possibly the most proudly mindless epic of the year.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Not that the characters matter, because the screenwriters and director Stephen Sommers are determined to mainly deliver one high-octane, heavily CGI-laden action set piece after another, to ultimately deadening effect.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's dumb. It's digital. It's derivative. This Joe, scripted at a toy-selling TV-cartoon level, is a non-stop shoot-em-up edited to induce seizures.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's knowing about the killing, and waiting for it to happen on the screen that gives the film its energy and thrust.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a seminal rock doc, and the actual music is only a small part of the magic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: When, as happens on several occasions, Amelia and Pippo become an integral part of the impressionistic film that surrounds them, instead of just being witnesses to it, Ginger and Fred ranks with the best work Mr. Fellini has ever done.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film isn't a particularly pleasurable experience (the satire of television is broad and wayward, and the attempts to wring pathos from Ginger and Fred's geriatric infirmities fall far short of the mark), but it does have a cranky, old-man's integrity.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Randle] holds the film together as best she can with her luminous presence and dignity, but can't supply the lacking subtext, past history and motivation.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's something refreshing about the film's reckless proximity to anarchy, the stylishly imaginative cinematography and lusciously exorbitant Prince soundtrack, even if it does ring hollow when Lee tries to get serious on us.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Lee has done the impossible: He's sucked the fun out of call-in sex and replaced it with sanctimonious prattle.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While Lee is a skillful director, he's also more coldly analytical than emotional, and it is not his style to get us to feel for this woman as much as we should.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Lee draws his lines between fantasy and reality without much confidence and with only a sketchy logic.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Frenetic but lazily conceived, it's like one of those puny low-budget toss-offs Brian De Palma used to spring on us when he thought nobody was looking.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Strongly told stories have a way of carrying their characters along with them. But here we have an undefined character in an aimless story. Too bad.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Lee may have a keen sense of setting and dialogue, but his characterization is off.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Instead of effervescent and mercurial, the movie is simply muddled. What happened?

item.label: rotten
item.content: This movie I think really did the impossible. It makes Failure To Launch look like The Thin Man.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's a tired premise with some even weaker gags.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I'm almost embarrassed to admit I found Ghosts of Girlfriends Past the season's first genuine guilty pleasure.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Only two characters might qualify as sympathetic.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Please, ladies, don't go see this movie. (Chances are most men would rather put out their eyes than go see a film with such a title.)

item.label: rotten
item.content: A junky-looking romantic comedy that's neither remotely romantic nor passably comic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As a romcom, it's average, but as a Matthew McConaughey romcom, it's above average. If you're a low-expectations moviegoer, this one might surprise you.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jennifer Garner is sweet and radiant as McConaughey's childhood friend and former lover; Lacey Chabert steals scenes as the woman marrying McConaughey's brother; and Robert Forster and Anne Archer are good as her parents.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Every audience member with an intellect bigger than a squid's knows at all times where Ghosts is heading.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ghosts of Girlfriends Past doesn't do Dickens any favors, but in a year that brought us Bride Wars, it'll do.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You've got to love a movie that so eagerly assassinates its leading man's cuddly image, and which also manages to blow a wicked kiss to Fatal Attraction.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's precious little to laugh at - not the lead's one-dimensional swagger, Michael Douglas's Rat Pack-meets-Robert Evans jive talk or an anti-misogyny parable with the gall to make every female a neurotic shrew or a sex-starved harpy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ghosts of Girlfriends Past never comes as close as spitting distance to a laugh.

item.label: rotten
item.content: McConaughey's character is finally forced to face up to past transgressions; one day, the filmmakers behind this rancid, hypocritical farce will have to deal with theirs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A bizarre conflation of chick flick and A Christmas Carol.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Douglas, radiating an arid narcissism, does look as if he was recently exhumed. Whether this is a deliberate makeup choice or unfortunate lighting is hard to guess.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The formulaic story evaporates faster than cotton candy, and it's often as cloyingly sweet and tacky.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Does it matter that every time Jolie's offscreen the film wilts a little? Ryder should be perfect as the bright spark; her lines are sharp as a knife. There's a gap, however, between what we hear and what we see.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film generates real empathy, without too much let's-laugh -at- the -crazy- people humor or too much stereotyping.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It has neither the clarity nor strength of purpose to engage an audience much beyond the converted.

item.content: Unsatisfying and unconvincing.

item.content: Unrelenting grimness settles over the movie like a soupy fog, changing shape only to add unnecessary suspense to the more ominous -- and obvious -- plot turns.

item.content: You can drive yourself crazy, or you can get over it. The choice is yours.

item.content: It's difficult to imagine any actress today bringing more sentience and intelligence to [Ryder's] role.

item.content: Not even foxy sociopath Angelina Jolie can save this nut-house drama.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: I would be more amused if the topic of rich material girls had not been worn to a thread elsewhere.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A teen movie I enjoyed enormously, much to my surprise.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mean Girls isn't a particularly deep picture, but it does have some weight and ballast.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mean Girls has a sharp, grown-up sensibility that belies its marketing as airhead comedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Boasts a one-two-three punch in star Lindsay Lohan, screenwriter Tina Fey and director Mark Waters, and, indeed, it delivers a knockout.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It all seems, finally, as if Fey is pulling her punches, an unusually defensive posture for her.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Waters tries for a tone that mixes dark humor and emotional realism, and he often finds it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tart and refreshing, Mean Girls is the kind of high-school movie that really feels as if it's for grown-ups -- but hey, the teens can come, too.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A smart little comedy that tries, within the limits of the teen-movie form, to say some real things about high school girls and the struggle for popularity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is the best film of its kind since Amy Heckerling's Clueless.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Fey subverts formula to find comic gold.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's that rare teen comedy that both teens and former teens can enjoy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Takes on issues of self-loathing, body image, competition and female sabotage. Even better, it does it with a smile.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's an improvement over the dire Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen, but Mean Girls is nowhere near as satisfying as Freaky Friday.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Fey's] snappy script and the deft direction of Mark Waters, who did Freaky Friday, keep the laughs coming.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With colorful characters and snappy performances, Mean Girls is a rare laugh-out-loud film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As a male writer-director, McKay proves to be extremely sensitive to the feeling and words of working-class women (Lili Taylor among them), determined to establish their self-worth as well as to fight against the social ills of the oppressive system

item.label: rotten
item.content: Taylor, Harris and Grace come up with some watchable, genuine moments. But they're often too involved in themselves; the movie indulges them too much.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film feels utterly real.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Features good work from its performers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The performances and the film's plausible handling of an unusual movie subject make Girls Town special.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Does an excellent job of uncovering the angst, pressure, and doubt associated with the late teenage years.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Constructed without a traditional denouement, Girls Town will nevertheless satisfy viewers who want something that feels more like life than like art.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A welcome little gust of teen-age realism.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I would like to see another movie in three or four years, about what has happened to these angry, gifted friends.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The script, put together by Samuel Gallu, is beautifully articulated and balanced.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The main thrust of the theatrical event is intact, and so's the Truman spirit.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Token attempt at street cred: if Paul doesn't get the tapes back, he'll be taken over by a sunglasses-wearing business shark.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Give My Regards to Broad Street is about as close as you can get to a nonmovie, and the parts that do try something are the worst.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A lot of effort has gone into this film's production values, but continuity seems, at best, to have been a secondary concern.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You could call it a self-serving film, were McCartney's complacency not so all-embracing: self-flattery requires at least a hint of self-doubt, but there's no trace of anything remotely that unsettling on McCartney's placid, Buddha-like brow.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The fusion of the ancient and the modern -- even to the point of some sly echoes of our own sports-mad society -- is seamless. Gladiator does indeed deliver the glory that was Rome, but it also clinically dissects the assumptions on which it was built.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Gladiator's combination of grim sanctimony and drenching, Dolby-ized dismemberings left me appalled.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Time for a little gladiatorial gore with your Milk Duds. Gladiator is here, and it's big, glorious and eminently dumb

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ultimately, Gladiator is an honorable and inoffensive spectacle with nothing extraordinary to recommend it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though the digital effects lack the weight and conviction of their equivalents in old Cecil B. De Mille movies, Ridley Scott's sword-and-sandal epic has some of the intensity of old Hollywood in terms of storytelling, spectacle, and violence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The cast is strong (notably Nielsen as Commodus's vacillating sister, and the late Oliver Reed, unusually endearing as a gladiator owner), the pacing lively, and the sets, swordplay and Scud catapults impressive.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The Roman costume drama, all dressed to the IX's, has taken a long holiday from the big screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A visually astonishing picture that brings script, performance and, alas, displays of violence up to the modern standard.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With its conspicuous display of prefascist trappings, it says more about our time than about Rome.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Highly visual entertainment with lots of blood and action.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Gladiator derides 'entertainment' while hustling like crazy to provide two and a half hours' worth of same. The heroism and the tigers and the epic grandeur all leave behind the flavor of cynicism.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Without Russell Crowe's dynamism holding it all together, Gladiator might have devolved into a rash of overblown pandering.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Self-proclaimed 'world-creator' Scott only intermittently obliterates the turgid narrative and mediocre dialogue.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The most visually spectacular of all Roman Empire epics.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gladiator charges into heart pounding battle.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film looks muddy, fuzzy and indistinct.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If spectacle, not plot, is your plate of pasta, you'll find Gladiator as much fun as a Roman holiday.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gladiator looms as an audacious, if not exactly great, movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Unless you're the rare 'Glee' fan who fast-forwards through the singing, 'Glee: The Concert Movie' won't fail to entertain.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I'm still not a Gleek, but I can see what all the fuss is about.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie makes a strong argument for the tender paradox of pop-culture adoration. It's an affection that feels wholly personal, but is shared with millions.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The layers of artifice are many, but they always are; the original show has never aspired to be anything but a cheeky, tuneful and multicultural spin on hoary high school stereotypes.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Don't be puzzled; just go with it -- that's the Glee spirit.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's something a little off about a stage show that features well-paid actors reenacting \"loser\" characters [that] fans take to heart, before leaving in what were surely limos and jets.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [It] would have worked just as well as a heavily promoted special television event broadcast over Thanksgiving weekend.

item.label: rotten

item.content: If you can survive the F-bombs and the near-constant ethnic invective, Gran Torino is not to be missed, if only as the gutsy, thoroughly unexpected valedictory of an icon fully willing to spend every bit of his considerable capital.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With Gran Torino, Eastwood has taken what might have been the likable last gasp of his iconic persona and turned it into the dullest, most heavy-handed sermon of his career.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film is neither elegant nor subtle. Both Eastwood's performance and his direction veer from broad melodrama to broader comedy and back again. But the film boasts crusty humor, heart and conscience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Writer-director Isao Takahata, a frequent collaborator of Miyazaki's at Studio Ghibli, adapted a partly autobiographical novel by Akiyuki Nosaka, and his handling of the tragic story is masterfully understated.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An emotional experience so powerful that it forces a rethinking of animation.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A chatty, colorful, nicely sardonic account of how a crisis led Mr. Gray to assess his medical state, consider his mortality and take one more funny, self-dramatizing look at the eccentric world around him.

item.label: rotten
item.content: At best, Gray is a tragicomic Everyman who strikes an empathic chord in his admiring audience; at worst, he's a middle-aged, self-absorbed, hopelessly provincial New Yorker -- an urban hick who won't shut up.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gray's Anatomy finds Spalding Gray turning a bout with a bizarre ocular condition into a dizzying, absorbing odyssey of the neurotic mind.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's something intrinsically insincere about the whole quest. Gray is on a search less for a cure than for material.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The screenplay is a prepubescent shambles, the direction is by acne out of disposable douches, the dubbing and looping of the songs is painfully obvious, the characterizations are generally repulsive and the whole thing is utterly without style.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Travolta is a riot. Alternately swaggering to prove his \"coolness\" and re-affirming his ability on the dance floor, the actor gives the kind of performance that's perfect for the role.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Grease holds up for new generations because it captures the enthusiasm of youth and the vibrancy of California's sunshine-and-cars culture.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Grease has got it, from the outstanding animated titles of John Wilson all the way through the rousing finale as John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John ride off into teenage happiness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Limp, cheaply made.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An unembarrassed movie musical, something my generation experienced only in Sunday-afternoon movies on TV.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Its flashy opportunism (nostalgia pitched squarely at an audience too young to even recall the era) quickly becomes very irritating.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Its sensibility is not tied to the past but to a free-wheeling, well informed, high-spirited present.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Grease is a great 'fun movie'.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Just an average musical, pleasant and upbeat and plastic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The friskiness of the performers, the choreography by Patricia Birch and most of all Travolta's phenomenal charm give it its value.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A pleasing if not surprising sampler of apercus, bon mots and clips.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Rarely have clips from so many good and great movies been put to such dull use.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The number of interviewees makes the film a signpost survey, more meaningful to film- study newbies than veterans.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a meat-and-potatoes espionage yarn that passes by quickly enough and meets the requirement of making us try to guess: Who is Salt?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Great Directors is not a great film, but in moments like these we feel as though we're eavesdropping on genius.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film never comes together into a cohesive whole and, ironically enough, the clips from the directors' films sometimes slow it down.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film jumps around in dizzying disorganization, illustrating the fact that part of what a director provides to a film is not just vision and leadership, but also, as the word suggests, a narrative direction.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Apprently novice filmmaker Angela Ismailos' definition of a Great Director is one who's willing to sit or walk with her while she lobs innocuous questions and gives herself lots of awed close-up reaction shots.

item.label: rotten
item.content: French bad-girl director Catherine Breillat says some interesting stuff, but what would be even more interesting is footage revealing how the novice filmmaker got to hang with the artists she calls her ''heroes.''

item.label: fresh
item.content: Her eclectic pantheon weighs in with entertaining anecdotes and illuminating comments, illustrated with well-chosen samplings of the artists' work.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Received ideas, creative-class cheerleading, and outright schmoozing bore, but the yacht party after the Cannes screening sounds awesome!

item.label: fresh
item.content: It should touch all those interested in the creative process.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: McTeague is surely a great novel, but one reason Greed is even better is that Stroheim had more lived experience to bring to the material.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Von Stroheim's rep, after a long dormancy, has been on the rise, and this is the best evidence of his work you'll get until someone finds those lost five hours in some Ukrainian subcellar.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As a study of stasis and of people conscious of not living the lives they had imagined for themselves, the picture offers a bracing undertow of seriousness beneath the deceptively casual, dramatically offhand surface.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A film of powerful, memorable moments -- some striking dialogue, some great performances, a handful of beautifully played, bracingly discomfiting love scenes -- in search of a structure and, perhaps, a soul.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Noah Baumbach again investigates psychologically screwed-up people, although this time with much less comedic impact.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Stiller is expert at playing self-indulgent types unaware of their boorishness, and Greenberg is no exception.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What saves it, however, is Gerwig. The love story ain't credible, but her performance is, perfectly capturing a young woman who doesn't lack confidence so much as a sense of self.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In many ways this is Baumbach's best film, filled with his bitter but often funny misanthropic perspective, but buoyed by the undeniable likability of Stiller and Gerwig.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie has the easy, unforced feel of the temporary timeout in life that Roger himself has embarked on. The script is full of funny, observant lines.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie ends on strange note, almost as if even Baumbach couldn't stand to spend one more minute with the odious Greenberg.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Baumbach may paint miniatures, but his films are anything but quaint. They're as unsettling as meeting a harmless but difficult stranger.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even among the cavalcade of finks and egoists that populate Baumbach's body of work, Greenberg is a doozy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Greenberg won't be everyone's cup of hemlock. Yet we all know people like this -- the ones who only hear their own motors running -- and Baumbach locates and mines a rich vein of appalled comic sympathy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Stiller's portrayal is so acutely real, Baumbach's writing so cutting and specific, and the work of Gerwig so seemingly effortless that Greenberg makes you, if not happy to stick around, then at least agreeable to the idea.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Stiller plays a monster, and when Gerwig goes for him, declaring that she sees his tender side, the development seems like a fond indulgence on the part of writer-director Noah Baumbach.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Cinematographer Harris Savides captures the relentless, rather terrifying sunniness of LA without ignoring the smog. Baumbach's script and direction has brought out the best in everyone on-screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I never knew who Ben Stiller was born to play, but now I do.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As unlikable as Roger is, Stiller finds a way to make you see past his bitterness and sympathize with his aimlessness. You don't like him, but you feel his pain.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Greenberg would be a heckuva movie if we could just get Greenberg out of there.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The funniest and saddest movie Mr. Baumbach has made so far, and also the riskiest.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Greenberg will do a lot for Stiller's reputation and Gerwig's profile, but its awkward, messy humanity and uncomfortable honesty won't necessarily do a lot for ticket-buyers more used to lighter, warmer and breezier entertainments.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The plot is too laboriously constructed, and the reason for the murders appears too incredible.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One of Launder and Gilliat's most likeable films.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Green For Danger will give the aisleside sleuths a better workout than they have had for months and it also will rest easily with those who are content just to sit back and let the story resolve itself.

item.label: rotten
item.content: How many more of these superheroes can we take?

item.label: rotten
item.content: He's an ambiguously...heroic hero.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Apart from having no particular reason to exist onscreen, especially at these prices, it's not half bad.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The result makes the movie seem assembled from bits and pieces of other superhero yarns rather than existing on a plane of its own.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The superhero genre is the home-court of the underdog, of skinny Peter Parkers and mutant outcasts, of heroes born from pain or ingenuity. In Green Lantern, the rich get richer.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even by the standards of the current run of mediocre comic-book movies, this one stands out for its egregious shoddiness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As a disjointed rumble in the cosmos, it's both too much and too little, and too dorky looking. In this case, Green means stop.

item.label: fresh
item.content: At least the filmmakers acknowledge that Reynolds in green tights and mask still looks like his non-Green Lantern alter ego, cocky test pilot Hal Jordan. There's none of this Clark Kent/Superman silliness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's almost as if no one cared to try hard enough to tell a coherent and engaging story.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [The] movie groans with the strain of explaining who Green Lantern is, while also trying to sell the movie as a big, eye-popping summer entertainment. What gets sacrificed on the altar of this new franchise launch is any real sense of fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Neither amusing nor exciting enough to ensure a long-running franchise.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A relentlessly silly superhero flick with eyeball-rolling dialogue - set in vast, familiar-looking digital realms that look like rejected models from the second \"Star Wars\" trilogy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Lantern rarely taps the charm Reynolds has shown in previous films. Consequently, it's hard to imagine why the nebulous Corps chose a cypher such as Hal as its savior.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The result is a deadly disappointment, despite Ryan Reynolds's cocky, muscle-flexing charisma.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Half-campy, half-compelling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Green Lantern opens with the words \"Billions of years ago...\" Take that as a sign of just how much time this ostensible action movie spends explaining itself.

item.label: fresh
item.content: More science-fiction space opera than superhero epic, it works in fits and starts as its disparate parts go in and out of effectiveness, but the professionalism of the production make it watchable in a comic book kind of way.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Apart from some spiffy visual effects, which create coherent, scary textures and architecture for outer space, Green Lantern is the most generic of summer time wasters.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Greengrass concocts a formula with a fighting chance of dispelling the Curse of the Hollywood Iraq Movie. If a picture as conventionally accessible as Green Zone tanks, that campaign is surely lost.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Green Zone hits hard and doesn't forgive. It plays out like fiction, and in some ways it is. But in too many ways, it's not.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Too little and too late? Maybe. But even in this Bourne Zone, Damon and Greengrass haven't shirked their duty to enlighten and entertain.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a tribute to Matt Damon's special quality as an actor -- not his star wattage, but his ability to project a certain simple human decency -- that we care about him even when we only see the side of his head...

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.content: Gremlins is far more interested in showing off its knowledge of movie lore and making random jokes than in providing consistent entertainment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A rich, well-crafted documentary that offers a rare glimpse at someone who respected Mother Nature but refused to live by her rules.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's an uncompromising character study of a man who found peace, and ultimately death, among some of the most dangerous predators on the planet.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What makes Grizzly Man remarkable are the edited tapes that at first seem to show a man at peace among nature, and then later reveal the startlingly fragile state of that man's mind and persona.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As unsettling as it is fascinating.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As a filmmaker, in Herzog's opinion, Treadwell was without equal. But as a naturalist, well, let's just say that his canteen had sprung a leak.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Grizzly Man is a haunting and fascinating portrait of so much that is worth exploring: the implacability of nature, the hubris of human endeavor and the line between supreme dedication and madness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is shaping up to be another great year for documentaries and this is one of the best.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Amazing documentary.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A Shakespearean character study that packs the sheer terror of The Blair Witch Project.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Grizzly Man approaches greatness for all the things it touches on and the one thing it resists.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sublime.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Grizzly Man is the strange, sad and mesmerizing tale of a man who wanted to be a bear.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although the film has sympathy for its subject's idiosyncrasy, Herzog makes it clear that he strongly disagrees with Treadwell's sentimental view of nature.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Despite some early indications from the two Cusacks and Arkin that it's going to be funny, it winds up an unholy mess that becomes steadily more incoherent -- morally, dramatically, and conceptually.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Cusack is charming and assured in the film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For what is essentially a one-joke movie, this has an awful lot going for it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A soggy, all-over-the- place mess.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An entertaining oddity, an amiably black comedy whose bared teeth double as an engaging smile: It takes a satiric bite and leaves you laughing through the pain. For that, we can thank the writers.

item.content: A bright burst of action and comedy with a cast that makes for rousing good company.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Clever enough to make jokes about Greco-Roman wrestling and make them funny, Grosse Pointe Blank's greatest success is the way it maintains its comic attitude.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film offers sufficient small pleasures to make it worth enduring the less effective elements. As a result, while Grosse Pointe Blank fails to deliver a fullisade, at least the chamber's not empty, either.

item.content: The film takes the form but not the feel of a comic thriller. It's quirkier than that.

item.content: Sembene, with a tense restraint, evokes a dependent country that maintains its dignity through nationalist pomp and local pride, and portrays one long-suffering family that bears Senegal's burdens in microcosm.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sembene is hardly a didactic director and in fact invests his characters with such complexities that they are sometimes compromised.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Alternately wise and very funny in its treatment of tribalism and in its grasp of neocolonial corruption.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A rich, vivid and universal portrait of a community that is revealed fully as it reacts to a crisis: a community that will be buried by the past if it cannot look to the future. There's a lesson here, and Mr. Sembene presents it with grace and ease.

item.content: Guess Who uses two-fifths of the title and gives us one-tenth the entertainment value.

item.content: There's never a question how things will turn out. (If you don't know: Recent Hollywood movies about interracial romance usually turn out well if the guy is white and almost always end tragically if he's black.)

item.content: A disappointing retread of a bunch of better movies.

item.content: Somewhere by the middle, the souffle collapses, and the movie becomes sleep-inducing. Gulliver doesn't have much to do in Lilliput, and we notice that before he does.

item.content: Kids might enjoy some of Black's wacky antics, but adults will tire of them fast.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This chronicle of a Gypsy-music package tour is a powerful rejoinder to rock-doc navel-gazing. Stunning performance excerpts, ranging from Spanish flamenco to Indian raga, demonstrate that keening brass choirs are just one aspect of the Gypsy sound.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's easy to see why [director] Dellal had trouble turning the camera off, especially when confronted with a startling and sad plot twist. Viewers are urged to grab an aisle seat, the better to dance when the music moves them -- as it surely will.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: As a music document and as a labor of unabashed love, the nonfiction feature Gypsy Caravan could hardly be better; as a movie, it could stand some improvement.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bright, campy and wonderfully light, Hairspray reminds us that fun comes in all shapes and sizes. It's also one of the few 'event' movies this summer that doesn't outstay its welcome. That's worth singing about, no matter what your name is.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's amiable, it's bouncy, it's got a sweet unknown in the lead flanked by a cast of bankable stars and, providing as it does an amiable and bouncy and sweet escape from a summer's worth of clunky blockbusters.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is so bad.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's a trumped-up bit of nonsense that goes nowhere.

item.label: rotten
item.content: After several scenes of this tacky nonsense, you'll be wistful for the testosterone-charged wizardry of Jerry Bruckheimer productions, especially because Half Past Dead is like The Rock on a Wal-Mart budget.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Absent one original moment and bathed in de rigueur steel blue punctuated by sporadic bursts of flaming orange, the movie is notable only for its creative approach to Seagal's bulky gracelessness.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.content: The most depressing thing of all is that Michael will likely survive even this dire endeavour.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
