item.label: rotten
item.content: This one represents Rob Zombie's \"vision.\" That being the case, he's blind.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Zombie remains committed to showing how violence lingers with, and perverts, all who are touched by it, yet his carnivalesque approach often undercuts his very real empathy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With his new sequel, Zombie spends less time paying tribute and more time getting inventive, with mixed results.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Zombie isn't a storyteller, he's a wallower. And because his movies take place in a culture of violence and sadism, there's nothing for Michael Myers to do except echo what's already there and slaughter weaker sadists.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's not even as scary as his Halloween remake, and that one was perfunctory, at best.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: This movie isn't horrible, but it seems like a waste for Zombie to keep revisiting someone else's world.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: As delivered by director Peter Berg, Hancock is never as serious or funny or poignant as it could be. And despite clocking in at a reasonable running time, it has a big sag in the middle that nothing could have fixed.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Tilting his elegantly aquiline features downward while hoisting one eyebrow over a dark orb, curling his lips with Grinchian deliberation, he seems to be determined to kill people on the strength of his cologne alone.

item.content: If they were going to show how he got to be the brilliant, charming, exquisitely cultured, uh, vicious cannibal psychopath -- couldn't they have come up with something more interesting?

item.content: You can argue that prequels to great films simply shouldn't be made. But when they are, this is the right way to do it.

item.content: The great thing about monsters is that they glide noiselessly from nightmare straight into myth, fully formed and eternally mysterious. To know what made them is to explain them. And once you explain anything, you begin to lose your fear of it.

item.content: Lichtenstein dutifully unpacks the family's unhappy past, but he's so easily distracted by surreal dream sequences and colorful supporting characters that his main story gradually dries up into a sitcom.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Happy Tears, is simply weird. The funny has gone missing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Happy Tears is less of a mess than it looks like, despite its quirk-infested, baggy midsection.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In this year's crop of Oscar-nominated shorts, the animated category beats the live-action offerings.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Moore steals Happy Tears by underplaying -- in what may be the warmest performance of her career.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A take-no-prisoners movie from one of Hong Kong's most idiosyncratic, shoot-from-the-hip filmmakers that's the very antithesis of sentimental gay love stories.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You don't watch this film as much as grab on to it. Letting it jerk you every which way is a jangly but interesting ride.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Wong doesn't show us any of the sparks that can still be struck between lovers who argue constantly.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sexy, spiky love story.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Wong continues to demonstrate his effortless command of the camera.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Were Kerouac, William Burroughs and Allen Ginsberg alive today, and able to see what Wong has done here ... they'd be thrilled and invigorated.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai reveals yet another facet of this always-unpredictable filmmaker: a flair for compassionate, humane melodrama.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A quiet, narratively layered period drama with a focus squarely on character.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Miike can't seem to get enough of Hanshiro's heroics. That's not just visual excess, though.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's an indelible picture of a cold-hearted ruling class that has allowed self-interest and hypocrisy to override its own humanity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Miike brings a formal, elegant restraint to his usual flair for wild theatrics.

item.label: fresh
item.content: More moving than shocking, it proceeds slowly and gracefully, and the few scenes of bloodshed are emotionally intense rather than showily sensational.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With this sober, mournful, gorgeously mounted and marvelously acted drama, Miike connects himself to the greatest traditions of Japanese film and to the period of historical self-examination that followed the debacle of World War II.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ryuichi Sakamoto's score, Nobuyasu Kita's cinematography and the performances are all impressive.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Miike turns the format's inherent limitations, especially the tendency toward visual murkiness, to his advantage, fully immersing us in a world suffused with moral and ethical rot.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It may well be Miike's best film, a patient, ominous piece of epic storytelling that conscientiously rips the scabs off the honorable samurai mythology.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A smarmy proposition passing itself off as family fun in the style of The Bad News Bears.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Works where it counts, on the emotional level.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's nothing wrong with a good cry, or a good cliche, and Hardball offers both by the barrel.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Just dreadful.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A misshapen mess which relies on shameless manipulation and cute casting to cover its lack of a plot and phony emotions.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll do exactly what this formula hip-hop baseball saga wants you to do.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is a film designed not so much to tell a coherent and moving story as it is to deliver a van full of cinematic groceries to a certain audience.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie is so littered with cliches of genre, as well as cliches of artifice in Reeves' pained performance, that any semblance of social reality goes foul.

item.label: rotten
item.content: We're always aware of the formula--and in a picture based on real life, we shouldn't be.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Choreographically stunning like most of Woo's work, especially before he headed West.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A supercharged thriller.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. Woo does, in fact, seem to be a very brisk, talented director with a gift for the flashy effect and the bizarre confrontation.

item.label: fresh
item.content: ... an enjoyable if incomplete nostalgia trip.

item.label: fresh
item.content: American Hardcore, Paul Rachman's impressively thorough documentary, tells of the second-generation punk rockers who learned from the Sex Pistols and Ramones and then did their DIY thing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: American Hardcore gets what most music lovers could not at the time: Sometimes, that noise in your head and that anger in your heart just has to get out, and there's always a guitar around somewhere.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Instead of an insightful look at disaffected youths finding an outlet for angry energy in rock rages, American Hardcore is a slanted history lesson coming solely from its subjects.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Leaves little doubt that this truly was one of the wildest eras in rock.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A valuable chronicle of a brief and snarling musical movement.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's a lot of interesting material here, but Rachman doesn't offer any real analysis of his own, and the film suffers from a lack of narrative focus.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film's a pretty good scrapbook ... and it evinces a healthy cranky-old-man disgust with the mega-platinum punk acts of today.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The documentary is an enlightening journey to a dark corner of contemporary punk's dank little basement.

item.label: fresh
item.content: American Hardcore is illuminating nostalgia, stuffed with all the right tattooed talking heads (like Black Flag's Henry Rollins), plus grim-looking concert footage of wailing skinny guys.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If it all goes by too fast, and leaves you with a headache when it's done -- well, wasn't that the point all along?

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Has ... meaning and truth, not to mention scarred humanity.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: The result is utter confusion.

item.content: A disappointing American debut of the Hong Kong cult director John Woo is a decent action vehicle by standards of its star Jean-Claude Van Damme but, hampered by a B script and flat characters, it doesn't bear Woo's auteurist signature and unique vision

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's what Hollywood wanted Woo for: bigger, brighter explosions.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Presenting Mr. Van Damme as reverentially as Sergio Leone did the young Clint Eastwood, Mr. Woo displays a real aptitude for malignant mischief, which is this story's stock in trade.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Even when the acting is hammy, notably Wilford Brimley's turn as Chance's Cajun uncle, Woo stages every fight with hypnotic grace.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Woo, a master of stylized violence and explosive action, has had to buy into America's fascination with explosive effects and reaction. Something gets lost in the transition.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Its characters are poorly-developed, the plot is the pinnacle of absurdity, and the acting, at best, is well over-the-top. Nevertheless, on the most basic, visceral level, the film succeeds.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Essentially, Hard Target is a risk-averse Van Damme vehicle, steered by many hands, and set on tracks leading directly to the delivery entrances of the country's video stores.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: An uninspired cross between Cotton Club and the characters of Damon Runyon, told in cliches so broad you keep waiting for it to poke fun at itself, but it never does.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film is carried by its charismatic stars, John Cho as Harold and Kal Penn as Kumar. Kumar plays Laurel to Harold's Hardy, continually getting the pair into messes. Cho is a marvel at displaying exasperation, his face contorting into a frown.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Offers a mix of nasty toilet jokes and sex gags, but the gratuitous nudity (male and female) and crazy cannabis-ness are there to serve a greater good: to mock social and political hypocrisy, a culture steeped in prejudice and pretense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The whole film feels easily distracted and apt to laugh at anything. But that's okay. So is its target audience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [The movie's] idiocy serves the cause of good sense and intelligence. And no, I'm not smoking anything.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's simply the tale of a man who decides to do something and sticks to his guns, so to speak. That the man is played by Michael Caine is what makes it worthwhile.

item.label: rotten
item.content: On one side, it's all compellingly believable; on the other, it's simply incredible. We do our best to straddle the rift but, in the end, the gulf proves too wide, the contrast too great, and a tumbling movie takes us down with it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film ranks right up there with Sleuth, Get Carter and Mona Lisa as being amongst Cainea(TM)s toughest and best performances.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Such familiarity can breed contempt among all but the most bloodthirsty, and it would in Harry Brown as well if not for Caine, who somehow breathes life into the most cardboard of characters.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Most viewers, especially the younger ones, will reap its joys.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Just as there is more magic conjured up in Chamber of Secrets the book, Chamber of Secrets the movie weaves a more powerful spell over its audience.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: The whole Harry Potter thing may not be as fresh for moviegoers as it was last year, but thankfully Chamber of Secrets is well-crafted.

item.label: fresh
item.content: While it still falls short of becoming the classic fans so badly want it to be, the film is livelier and better overall than The Sorcerer's Stone, mostly because J.K. Rowling got all that tiresome exposition over with the first time out.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This movie, like the first, is more of a translation than an adaptation. It's the visual equivalent of an audio book, slightly abridged.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Dark, resonant, inventively detailed and packed with fleet turns of plot and a feast of visual amazement.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Not only are the special effects and narrative flow much improved, and Daniel Radcliffe more emotionally assertive this time around as Harry, but the film conjures the magic of author J.K. Rowling's books.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Entertaining and moves nimbly enough to keep your way-back seat from turning to stone.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I can't think of a movie this long that has left me so starved for a movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is superior to its predecessor in every way: It's more thrilling, more entertaining and, yep, more magical.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Radcliffe, Watson and Grint, having literally grown up in their characters, are ready for their close-up. They earned it, they deserve it and they nailed it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Deathly Hallows I actually manages to be involving and kind of artful about the boredom and loneliness of heroism.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's plenty of humor, plenty of magic and even a bit of romantic stress, although there's also quite a bit of mulling and standing about.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The truth is that this film is mostly plain work, done by rote, like any introductory potions class. The real fun -- and thrills and tears -- come next year.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The three young leads -- especially Emma Watson, who can do more with a still face than any actress her age -- are all terrific.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Like a virgin's padded bra, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part I is all tease, zero payoff.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Alas, as directed by the returning David Yates, these big chase sequences are the usual compendium of ear-splitting noise and eye-glazing edits -- again, no magic required and none delivered.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The seventh and penultimate entry in the franchise jettisons the humor and fizz of the earlier movies for a much bleaker adult tone.

item.label: fresh
item.content: David Yates' fluid, fast-paced direction sends up the crackling tension of a thriller.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: The filmmakers...adapt Rowling's tale with as much fidelity as their budget, effects crew, production designers, actors, and common sense will allow.

item.content: This is the way The Harry Potter saga was meant to end.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: A lot of low-stakes humor, occasionally brought off by a mostly ingratiating cast.

item.content: For something like Horrible Bosses to sparkle, the actors have to shine... and shine they do.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Horrible Bosses offers a reminder that adherence to formula may not be among the signal virtues of comedy, but--provided the jokes are funny--it's no great vice either.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As they say, the best laid plans go oft awry. So what transpires in a comedy about the worst-laid schemes? These guys don't seem built for premeditated murder but are perfectly capable of mayhem.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Horrible Bosses takes a dark premise -- three buddies band together to off their bosses -- and rings it for a solid, steady stream of laughs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The screenplay is a hit and miss; but there are some laughs.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What's right about Horrible Bosses is less easy to identify, but it comes down to something like esprit de corps.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The smartest thing about \"Horrible Bosses\" is that it both refuses to just clock in and waste time - and, at the same time, works extra hard to hold our attention.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Bits that could have courted actual darkness a la Very Bad Things-violence, venality, vindictive sex-simply register as dank shock-jock gags done with little courage, and even less conviction.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's an underlying, nearly universal relatability to \"Horrible Bosses\" that can't be denied and that screenwriters Michael Markowitz, John Francis Daley and Jonathan Goldstein use to great advantage.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's over-the-top stuff, to be sure. But Bosses never crosses that line into the macabre. Don't call in sick to this shift.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Look at how crazy is the craziness we are doing for you. Isn't it crazy? the movie shouts, and the more it does, the less you'll laugh.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: The talented cast and colorful vulgarities work overtime to cover for a lack of coherence, but they can only distract for so long.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Watching good actors let their hair down can be fun, but watching them let their standards down isn't.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: The madcap Marxes, in one of their maddest screen frolics.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Riding in on the four ponies currently plaguing the Hollywood horror-thriller -- overstylized torture, whiplash editing, compulsive script reversals and crude neon lighting -- Horsemen brings its herd home to pasture in strictly predictable fashion.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: The sad thing is that this Horton doesn't stick by its central message -- that every voice counts -- the way Horton sticks to the Whos. It pretends to, but the sincerity is just too scary to commit to fully.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The team behind Ice Age capture the Seussian visuals without squishing emotions or squelching the sing-songy language. Listen closely: It's the sound of a million Who fans cheering.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Frequently charming, beautifully drawn and far more faithful in spirit to the source material than those dreadful Ron Howard-Brian Grazer productions.

item.label: fresh
item.content: And a motto moguls should take some time learning, if they'd like their movies to finally be earning, for it's not the cash that makes a prize of the art, but the warmth of the tale, and the size of the heart.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This Horton Hears a Who! never loses sight of the simple but perennially powerful theme at the heart of Seuss' tale: 'a person's a person, no matter how small.'

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: When Horton sticks to the sweet, funny spirit of its source, though, all's right with the worlds, big and little.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Compared with those mega-budget predecessors, the adaptation sticks pretty close to the text and tone of the book, faithful enough to earn its just reward.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Horton Hears a Who! brings a masterwork into the here and now with both respect and wide-eyed enthusiasm. So smart, so stimulating, so much fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Willis plays a man with a past whose nightmare returns when a hostage drama reopens old wounds, blah, blah, blah...

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.content: Hostel: Part II offers more hard-core horror and an even more outspoken message [than the first].

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ends up there is a moral to the story, one sure to delight the bamboozled pseudo-intellectuals who laughably defended Hostel as a geo-political critique of American arrogance and the culture of torture.

item.label: rotten
item.content: No doubt about it: Roth is a talented guy. But it would be nice to see him use his skills in the service of something other than more sadistic, pandering, pornographic violence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The great strength of Hotel Rwanda is that it's not about superhuman heroism but simply about human decency.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The almost forgotten but all too real African genocide documented in Hotel Rwanda hits us as suddenly and as hard as it does Paul Rusesabagina, the accidental hero played so masterfully by Don Cheadle.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It has a genuine power: the ability of film to beam light onto dark days of history, making it impossible for us to look away, reminding us of what we should never forget.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What makes the film not just harrowing but transcendent is Cheadle. He does nothing traditionally heroic. He just presents a picture of basic decency, showing how, when combined with courage, decency can result in an awe- inspiring moral steadfastness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: All we can do is hope that films such as Hotel Rwanda remind us all -- moviegoer and politician -- of the terrible cost of doing nothing.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Because of the subject matter, this feels like one of those films you see because it's good for you. But it also is an extraordinarily moving drama.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There is much to respect in Hotel Rwanda, not least Cheadle's subtly crafted performance, which allows the audience a direct connection to his ethical growth.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If Hotel Rwanda does nothing more than provoke the obvious questions of 'How did this happen?' and 'How can we prevent it from happening again?' it has, like the hotelier who refuses to consider himself a hero, done its job.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film serves as reminder and educator for those who've forgotten or never knew about the situation in Rwanda.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A story so powerful it can't help but speak to both the heart and the conscience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The world stayed out of Rwanda for fear of doing an imperfect job. Bold filmmakers are at their best when they mature beyond that kind of paralysis.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Cheadle gives one of the best performances (if not the best) of last year -- an Oscar-worthy portrait of a man who kept his head clear and his humanity intact in the midst of a man-made hell.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The twofold agenda in Hotel Rwanda is to commemorate what Paul Rusesabagina did and to shame each and every Westerner who sees the movie. On both of those counts it is successful.
